div2.p: Great men after their death would be more gratified by an encomium celebrating their achievements than by costly offerings and musical and athletic contests.
w)= *niko/kleis: see Introd. p. 21.
tw=n e)piferome/nwn: ‘offerings’ such as libations and sacrifices.

mousikh=| kai\ gumnikoi=s a)gw=sin: cp. Plato, Menex. 249 B pro\s de\ tou/tois a)gw=nas gumnikou\s kai\ i(ppikou\s tiqei=sa kai\ mousikh=s pa/shs. mousikh/ here probably includes literary as well as musical contests.
trih/rwn a(mi/llais: cp. the races for ships at the games commemorating the anniversary of the death of Anchises (Virg. Aen. v. 42 ff.).

lei/pont' ou)demi/an tw=n toiou/twn u(perbolh/n, ‘leaving to others no opportunity of surpassing you in such respects’; cp. de bigis 35 toi=s me/llousin i(ppotrofei=n ou)demi/an u(perbolh\n katalipw/n (of Alcibiades). u(perba/llein and the middle u(perba/llesqai mean either (1) ‘to excel’, ‘surpass’ (as in § 6, &c.), hence the above meaning of u(perbolh/, or (2) absolutely ‘to excel’ (as in § 41) or ‘to surpass all bounds’ (as in § 14), hence u(perbolh/ comes to mean ‘a wonderful extent’ (ei)s u(perbolh/n, § 23) and ‘exaggeration’ (§ 72), ‘excess’ (ad N. 33).

ei)/ tis e)sti\n ai)/sqhsis kte(: the usual Greek conception of life after death was that the dead lived a shadowy existence, which was a feeble imitation of their former life on earth. The question whether the dead know anything that is happening in the living world is frequently discussed in Greek literature and is raised elsewhere by Isocr. (Aeg. 42, Plat. 61). The most famous discussion is that in Plato's Apology 40 C duoi=n . . . qa/tero/n e)stin to\ teqna/nai: h)\ ga\r oi(=on mhde\n ei)=nai mhd' ai)/sqhsin mhdemi/an mhdeno\s e)/xein . . ., h)\ . . . metabolh/ tis tugxa/nei ou)=sa kai\ metoi/khsis . . . ei)s a)/llon to/pon.
e)nqa/de, ‘in this world.’
a)pode/xesqai, ‘welcome.’
kindu/nwn: i.e. in particular his plot against the usurper (§ 27-32) and his assistance to Conon (§ 52-7).
tw=n . . . pepragme/nwn: gen. after a)ci/ws, as also in § 40.
e)kei/nw|: the dative of the agent has a far wider use in Greek than in Latin, and is preferred to u(po/ with the genitive after verbs in the perfect passive; cp. § 38 tw=n tou/tw| pepragme/nwn.
a)nti\ tw=n toiou/twn: i. e. a)nti\ tou= ta\ toiau=ta labei=n, ‘preferring an encomium to all honours of this kind.’
peri\ au(tw=n: peri/ is one of the few words after which Isocrates admits a hiatus (it occurs also in § 21, 52, 71, ad N. 6, 11, 18, 28).

oi( peri\ th
 mousikh
 kte(., ‘those engaged in musical and other contests’; cp. § 8 oi( peri\ th
 filosofi/an o)/ntes, and for mousikh/, § 1.

oi( de\ peri\ th
 mousikh
 kai\ ta\s a)/llas a)gwni/as o)/ntes, oi( me
 ta\s duna/meis ta\s au(tw=n, oi( de\ ta\s te/xnas . . .: a good example of chiasmus; here te/xnas corresponds to mousikh/n, duna/meis to ta\s a)/llas (i. e. gymnastic) a)gwni/as.
duna/meis: here ‘physical strength’; for other meanings see N. C. 9, note.
kate/sthsan: gnomic aorist; cp. ad N. 7 pare/sxen . . . e)/laben.
o( lo/gos, ‘discourse’, ‘speech’.

Other writers ought to have praised their distinguished contemporaries and so stirred up the younger generation to emulate them. It is perhaps discouraging that the heroes of the Trojan war have been so celebrated by Epic and Tragic poets, that no one to-day, whatever his achievements, can hope for such fame. This feeling is due to jealousy, which is unworthy of a man of sense. In this discourse I am making a new departure; but no advance is made in any department of human activity, unless some one strikes out a new line.
tou\s e)f' au(tw=n a)/ndras, ‘their contemporaries’; cp. in Callim. 18 e)pi\ tw=n tria/konta, ‘in the time of the thirty’; contrast tou\s e)f' au(toi=s (N. C. 20), ‘their successors.’
kosmei=n, ‘glorify.’
e)n suneido/si poiou/menoi tou\s lo/gous: cp. Thuc. ii. 36 makrhgorei=n e)n ei)do/sin ou) boulo/menos e)a/sw.
tai=s a)lhqei/ais: Isocr. is very fond of using the plural of abstract words.

e)xrw=nto . . . die/keinto, ‘in order that . . . they might have told the truth, and that the younger generation might have been more dis
posed to emulate them.’ The past tense of the indicative is in final clauses after i(/na, w(s or o(/pws to express an unfulfilled purpose in present or past time. The principal sentence is either an unfulfilled wish or (as here) its equivalent, or an unfulfilled apodosis; cp. Soph. O.T. 1391 ti/ m' ou)labw\n e)/kteinas eu)qu/s, w(s e)/deica mh/pote kte(., ‘why did you not take and slay me at once, so that I might never have shown, &c.’

filotimote/rws: the form of the comparative adv. in Attic Greek is usually the acc. neut. sing. but Isocr. favours the form in -ws, cp. § 21 meizo/nws, ad N. 14 e)rrwmeneste/rws, N. C. 44 perittote/rws.

eu)logh/sontai: future middle with passive sense. Such forms are by no means uncommon in Attic Greek; I note four examples in a single chapter of Xenophon (Cyrop. vi. 1), viz. au)ch/setai, e)pibouleu/setai, poliorkh/sontai, tara/contai; cp. also ad Nic. 16 a)dikh/sontai.
tou/twn: gen. of the thing compared after ma=llon. w(=n a similar gen. after a)mei/nous.

tou\s me\n peri\ ta\ *trwi+ka/, ‘those who were engaged in the Trojan wars.’ For the use of peri/ cp. § 4 oi( peri\ th\n mousikh/n. With ta\ *trwi+ka/ we may compare such expressions as ta\ *mhdika/, ta\ *persika/.

tou\s e)pe/keina genome/nous, ‘those who lived still earlier.’ e)pe/keina, lit. ‘on the further side’, is used both of time (as here) and of place, cp. tou= *(hraklei/ou e)pe/keina (Xen. Hell. v. 1. 10). The reference is to the early heroes such as Heracles, Theseus, and the Argonauts. The scholiast has a note: oi(=on *)erixqo/nios, *)/inaxos, *eu)/molpos.

u(mnoume/nous kai\ tragw|doume/nous: the subjects of songs and tragedies. u(/mnos in a strict sense applies to songs such as the Homeric Hymns, the lost Hymns of Pindar, and dithyrambic poems in honour of heroes, such as the Theseus and Heracles of Bacchylides; but the verb u(mnei=n is also used in a wider sense (= Latin celebrare), and so here the reference is probably also to the Iliad and Odyssey and the lesser epics. The Greek tragedians took their plots in almost every case from legendary history; the Persae of Aeschylus is the sole exception among the tragedies which have come down to us.

au(to\n de\ proeidh=| . . . a)ciwqhso/menon, ‘foresees that, even if he surpasses their achievements, he will never be thought worthy of such praises.’ In the participial construction after verbs of knowing, seeing, &c., when the reflexive (au(to/n) is used, the participle (a)ciwqhso/menon) naturally agrees with the reflexive.
u(perba/llh|: see note on u(perbolh/n, § 1.

o( fqo/nos, w(=| tou=to pro/sestin kte(, ‘envy, about which this is the only good point, namely, that it is a far greater curse to those who are actuated by it than to any one else’; cp. de antidos. 13 bou/lomai tou\s fqonou=ntas e)/ti ma=llon u(po\ th=s no/sou tau/ths lupei=sqai, and Seneca, Ep. 81. 2 hoc (i. e. malitia) habentibus pessimum est.

ou(/tw ga\r dusko/lws kte(, ‘for some people are so ill-natured that they would rather hear those men praised of whose very existence they are ignorant, than men from whom they have themselves received benefits.’

ou(\s ou)k i)/sasin ei) gego/nasin: when verbs of knowing, &c., are constructed with a dependent clause, the subject of the dependent clause is often anticipated as the object of the verb of knowing; cp. oi)=da/ se o(/stis ei)=, ‘I know thee who thou art,’ and Plato, Euthyd. 294 C oi)=sqa *eu)qu/dhmon o(po/sous o)do/ntas e)/xei; and for a similar construction after a verb of showing N. C. 12 ei) proepidei/caimi . . . th\n politei/an w(s a)/cio/n e)sti.
ou) mh/n: mh/n with a negative means ‘but all the same’, ‘however’, cp. ou) me/ntoi in the same sense.

douleute/on tou\s nou=n e)/xontas: with the impersonal verbal construction the agent is usually in the dative, but in Attic Greek the accusative is also used, especially when (as here) there is another dative in the sentence; cp. Plato, Crito 49 A ou)deni\ tro/pw| fame\n e(ko/ntas a)dikhte/on ei)=nai, and Thuc. viii. 65 ou)/te misqoforhte/on ei)/h a)/llous h)\ tou\s strateuome/nous ou)/te meqekte/on tw=n pragma/twn ple/osin h)\ pentakisxili/ois, where both constructions are found. The acc. may be due to the analogy of the acc. after dei=.
toiou/twn: masculine.
tou\s a)/llous: the object of e)qiste/on, not the agent.

a)/llws t' e)peidh\ kai/: kai/ here qualifies ta\s e)pido/seis and cannot be taken with a)/llws te. The phrase a)/llws te followed by e)peidh/ or e)a/n is not uncommon in Isocr. (cp. ad N. 51 and Paneg. 66) and in other Attic writers, especially Xenophon. There is clearly some distinction between a)/llws te and the more common a)/llws te kai/ (‘especially’, lit. ‘both otherwise and’). Sandys, on Paneg. l. c., says that a)/llws te kai\ e)peidh/ ‘is more common, but less forcible than a)/llws t' e)peidh/’. The best explanation of the phrase a)/llws te is that a)/llws here means ‘otherwise’, i. e. ‘in a greater degree’,
so that the whole phrase a)/llws t' e)peidh/ will mean ‘still more so when’, ‘above all when’.
e)pido/seis, ‘advance’, ‘progress’ (a favourite word in Isocr.), from the intransitive use of e)pidido/nai. It also has a technical meaning ‘money advanced’ by citizens in an emergency of the state.
toi=s kaqestw=sin, ‘the established order of things.’
tou\s e)panorqou=ntas: sc. ta\ kaqestw=ta.
kinei=n, ‘to alter,’ i. e. ‘improve’ as in ad N. 17; in § 63 in bad sense, ‘tamper with’, ‘disturb’; cp. kinei=n ta\ a)ki/nhta.

Eulogy in prose is more difficult than in verse and has never before been attempted. The poet can employ embellishments of every kind, and rhythm and metre add a charm. However, the eulogist in prose must do his best.
dia\ lo/gwn, ‘in prose’; cp. Xen. Cyrop. i. 4. 25 e)n lo/gw| kai\ e)n w)|dai=s and the use of oratio in Latin, e. g. et in poematis et in oratione (Cic. Orat. 21).

shmei=on de\ me/giston: peri\ me\n ga/r: for the omission of e)sti/ and this use of ga/r (which is often omitted and which we should not translate in English) cp. § 51 me/giston de\ tekmh/rion: tw=n ga/r, and N. C. 21 to\ de\ me/giston . . . ga/r.
oi( peri\ th\n filosofi/an o)/ntes: cp. oi( peri\ th\n mousikh/n (§ 4). On the meaning of filosofi/a in Isocr. see Introd. p. 14.
ko/smoi, ‘means of embellishment.’
poih=sai, ‘represent.’ poiei=n has the generic meaning of ‘to do’, ‘to make’, and the specific meaning of to ‘compose’, ‘represent in poetry’, see note on § 36 poihsa/menos.
peri\ tou/twn dhlw=sai, ‘treat of these subjects.’
tetagme/nois o)no/masi, ‘current’ or ‘ordinary language’, also called ku/ria or politika\ o)no/mata (see below).
ce/nois, ‘out-of-the-way,’ i. e. either antiquated words or words taken from some other dialect; such words were often called glw=ttai (see below).
kainoi=s, ‘newly coined,’ called also pepoihme/na o)no/mata.
ei)/desi: sc. ko/smwn, ‘different kinds of embellishment.’

With the whole of this passage cp. Aristot. Poet. 1457^{b} 1 a(/pan
o)/noma/ e)stin h)\ ku/rion h)\ glw=tta h)\ metafora\ h)\ ko/smos h)\ pepoihme/non, ‘every word is either current or strange or metaphorical or ornamental or newly-coined.’ Thus ku/rion or tetagme/non or politiko\n (see below) o)/noma is the ordinary name for a thing. The rest are a)llo/tria o)no/mata. glw=ttai or ce/na o)no/mata are foreign or obsolete words and, according to Aristotle, must not be used in prose. kaina/ or pepoihme/na o)no/mata are newly-coined words, such as the strange compounds—r(h/mata gomfopagh=, ‘words pinned together with nails’—in which Aeschylus delighted. Of metaforai/ Aristotle enumerates several kinds, of which the most common is that from analogy; if you want a metaphor for ‘old age’, he says, you must reflect that old age : life :: sunset : day; accordingly you may call old age dusmai\ bi/ou, or the sunset gh=ras h(me/ras. Compare also Dionys. de comp. verb. 25 kai\ h( e)klogh\ tw=n o)noma/twn me/ga ti du/natai, kai\ e)/sti tis o)nomasi/a poihtikh/, glwtthmatikw=n te kai\ ce/nwn kai\ tropikw=n kai\ pepoihme/nwn, ‘the choice of words also is important and poetry has its own vocabulary, consisting of strange, out-of-the-way, figurative and newly-coined words.’
paralipei=n: cp. the Latin praetermittere.
diapoiki=lai, ‘diversify.’ poiki/los is properly used of things of varied pattern or colour, e.g. embroidery (Aesch. Agam. 923), a fawn's skin (Eur. Bacch. 249), and a peacock (Athen. 397 C).
toi=s peri\ tou\s lo/gous: see note on § 8 dia\ lo/gwn.
a)poto/mws: with a)nagkai=on, ‘absolutely’ (from a)po/, te/mnw), cp. the Latin praecise (from prae, caedo) and the English ‘sheer necessity’.

politikoi=s: politiko/s is lit. ‘of’ or ‘belonging to a citizen’; cp. ad N. 21 tw=n oi)/kwn tw=n politikw=n; so here of language ‘suitable to a citizen’, so ‘ordinary’, ‘current’, equivalent to tetagme/nos (§ 9). By an extension of meaning politiko/s can also mean ‘having to do with politics’; cp. ad N. 51 tw=n politikw=n (sc. lo/gwn), ‘political discussions,’ and § 46 politiko\s w)/n, lit. ‘being a suitable person to govern’, so ‘an able administrator’.

tw=n e)nqumhma/twn kte(, ‘those ideas which concern the actual facts.’ e)nqu/mhma is here used in its literal sense; later, in Aristotelian logic, it has the meaning of ‘a syllogism drawn from probable premises’.
me/trwn kai\ r(uqmw=n: metre is the arrangement of syllables so as to form verses; rhythm, the proportion and harmony produced by this arrangement.

e)kei=qen, ‘from the following consideration,’ referring forward to the sentence introduced by ga/r; cp. the regular use of e)kei=nos as the antecedent of the relative (= Latin is), and e)kei/nws . . . ei) (§ 39).

h)\n ga\r . . . ta\ me\n o)no/mata kte(, ‘if one retains only the words and ideas and breaks up the metre.’ With the whole of this passage cp. Plato, Republ. x. 601 B e)pei\ gumnwqe/nta ge tw=n th=s mousikh=s xrwma/twn ta\ tw=n poihtw=n, au)ta\ e)f' au(tw=n lego/mena, oi)=mai/ se ei)de/nai oi(=a fai/netai.
h(=s: the relative is here attracted into the case of its antecedent; cp. Xen. Anab. i. 3. 16 tw=| h(gemo/ni pisteu/somen w(=| a)\n *ku=ros didw=|.

pleonektou/shs: pleonektei=n (ple/on e)/xein) has two meanings (1) when ple/on means ‘more’, ‘to have more than some one else’, so ‘to have an advantage’ (as here), cp. pleoneci/as (N.C. 22), ‘advantages’; or (2) ‘to have too much’, so ‘to be greedy’ or ‘grasping’ as in § 20 and ad N. 24, and pleoneci/a (N.C. 1), ‘selfish end’.
ei), ‘to see if.’
The descent of Evagoras from Zeus, Aeacus, and Teucer, the founder of Salamis.
fu/sews, ‘birth,’ as in § 49; peri\ th=s fu/sews . . . kai\ ti/nwn h)=n a)po/gonos depend on proepi/stantai.
dielqei=n peri/, ‘describe,’ a more common meaning than the literal meaning ‘to pass through’. It usually governs a direct acc., e.g. in § 48.
o(mologei=tai me\n ga\r kte(, ‘it is generally admitted that the descendants of Zeus were the noblest of the heroes, and among these every one would assign the first place to the Aeacidae.’
tw=n kaq' au(tou/s, ‘their contemporaries,’ like tou\s e)f' au(tw=n (§ 5).
tou=to me/n: adverbial acc. ‘on the one hand’, ‘in the first place’, usually answered by tou=to de/, but here the construction is varied and a simple de/ follows.

tosou=ton dih/negken, ‘excelled’, ‘occupied so distinguished a position’. diafe/rein means (1) ‘to differ’, (2) by a slight extension of meaning ‘to surpass’; it is here used absolutely. In N.C. 19 diaferome/nous, ‘differing from one another’, ‘disputing’.
u(pere/ballen: see note on § 1 u(perbolh/n.
h)=lqon . . . i(keteu/ontes: note that the present participle (not the future participle of purpose) is used, ‘came with prayers.’
dia\ th=s suggenei/as: sc. *dio/s, ‘his kinship with Zeus.’
eu)sebei/as: Schneider quotes Plut. Theseus 10 *ai)ako\n *(ellh/nwn o(siw/taton nomi/zesqai.

i(ero/n: Pausanias (ii. 29. 7), who relates the same story of Aeacus, describes the shrine, which he calls the Aeaceion. It stood ‘in the most conspicuous part of the city’ (i. e. the capital of Aegina) and contained ‘sacred olive-trees, an altar, and statues of the Greeks who were sent to consult Aeacus’. The word i(ero/n must here be equivalent not to nao/s (‘temple’), but to te/menos (‘enclosure’, lit. ‘piece cut off’, from te/mnw, cp. Latin templum), a meaning which it also bears in Thuc. iv. 90, where the i(ero/n (at Delium) is distinguished from the actual building.

koino\n tw=n *(ellh/nwn: this shrine of Aeacus must not be confused with the Panhellenion, which was built by Aeacus and dedicated to Zeus, and stood on a hill (the modern Mt. Oros) outside the city (Paus. ii. 33. 3-4).
ou(=per, ‘on the very spot where.’ The enclitic per has an intensifying force.

kat' e)kei=no/n te to
 xro/non . . . e)peidh\ de/ (see critical note): to avoid the anacoluthon of te followed by de/, most editors emend de/ to te; Schneider, however, clearly shows that this is unnecessary, and quotes amongst other parallels Panath. 212, where the MSS. read sumbai/nei . . . e)/n te toi=s paisi
 eu)dokimei=n ma=llon tw=n a)/llwn, e)peida
 de\ kte(., and Thuc. i. 11. 1 to/n te strato
 e)la/ssw h)/gagon, e)peidh\ de\ kte(.
meth/llace, ‘quitted.’ metalla/ttein is lit. ‘to exchange by taking (or giving) something instead’.
*ko/rh|: the regular name for Persephone in Attica.
megi/stas tima/<*>s: Aeacus is often described as a judge of the underworld together with Minos and Rhadamanthus.

e)pi\ *laome/donta strateusa/menos: the reference is to the legendary expedition against Troy a generation earlier than the great Trojan war. Poseidon had helped Laomedon to build Troy, and, when Laomedon refused to reward him for his work, Poseidon sent a sea monster against the city. This monster was appeased each year by the sacrifice of a maiden. Heracles on his return from fighting with the Amazons found that Hesione, the daughter of Laomedon, was about to be sacrificed. He promised to slay the monster, if Laomedon would give him the famous horses which Zeus had given to
Troy. Hesione was saved, but again Laomedon refused the reward. Heracles therefore, assisted by Telamon, made an expedition against Troy and destroyed it, and slew all the sons of Laomedon except Priam.
a)ristei/wn: his reward, according to Apollodorus (xi. 6. 4), was the hand of Hesione, daughter of Laomedon.

th=| ma/xh| th=| pro\s *kentau/rous: i. e. the fight of the Lapiths and Centaurs at the marriage of Peirithous. This story was familiar to the Greeks from its frequent representation in art, e. g. on the western pediment of the Temple of Zeus at Olympia (Gardner, Gk. Sculpture, pp. 221 ff.) and on the metopes of the Parthenon (ib. pp. 270 ff.).
pollou\s a)/llous kindu/nous: in particular, he was one of the Argonauts.

a)qana/th|: in most Attic writers a)qa/natos is an adjective of two terminations. Isocr. does not use the feminine form elsewhere, but this is the only passage where it is used of a person; elsewhere it is applied to abstract conceptions mnh/mh (ad N. 37) do/ca (ib. 32), &c. Homer uses the feminine form when speaking of goddesses: cp. a)qa/natai a(/liai, ‘the immortal goddesses of the sea’ (Od. xxiv. 47).
mo/nou tou/tou kte(, ‘he was the only man of olden times at whose marriage the wedding hymn is said to have been sung by the gods’; namely, by Apollo, to whom Hera says:—
pa/ntes d' a)ntia/asqe, qeoi/, ga/mou: e)n de\ su\ toi=si dai/nu) e)/xwn fo/rmigga, kakw=n e(/tar), ai)e\n a)/piste.
(Hom. Il. xxiv. 62-3.)
Plato, Repub. 383 B, quotes a passage from a lost play of Aeschylus in which Thetis complains that Apollo sang at her marriage and afterwards slew her son.
tou/twn d' e(kate/rou kte(, ‘both of them had sons; Ajax and Teucer were sons of Telamon, and Achilles of Peleus.’

tou\s barba/rous: i. e. the Trojans. The connexion of Aegina with the two expeditions against Troy was fitly commemorated in the two pediments of the Temple of Aphaea in Aegina, the sculptures from which are now mainly in the Glyptothek at Munich, though the more recently discovered fragments are in Athens. The eastern pediment represents the expedition of Heracles and Telamon, the
western the later expedition (see Gardner, op. cit., pp. 201 ff.; Furtwängler, Glyptothek, pp. 77 ff.).

ou)deno\s de\ tw=n o)nomastw=n a)poleifqe/ntos, ‘no hero of distinction having absented himself’; lit. ‘having been left behind’. The various uses of a)polei/pein are well illustrated in this speech. Its literal meaning is ‘to leave behind’, so § 51 ta\s patri/das a)polipo/ntes, and in the passive here and in § 79. It is also used intransitively in the active (§ 71, see note). In the passive it is used (1) followed by a genitive (due to the idea of comparison), lit. ‘to be left behind by’, so ‘to be inferior’ (a)polelei=fqai, § 47), and ‘to fall short of’ (a)poleifqw= tw=n pepragme/nwn, § 48), and so N. C. 19 a)polei/pontai tw=n kairw=n, ‘they miss their opportunities’; (2) absolutely, ‘inferior,’ § 61 pa/sais a)poleleimme/nos tai=s duna/mesin, ‘inferior in resources of every kind.’

*salami=na kte(: Isocr. emphasizes the connexion between the town of Salamis in the east of Cyprus and the island of Salamis in the Saronic Gulf, near Athens, as evidence of the Greek descent of the family of Evagoras.
to\ ge/nos to\ nu=n basileu=on kate/lipen: cp. Paus. ii. 29. 3 oi( de\ *teukri/dai basilei=s die/meinan *kupri/wn a)/rxontes ei)s *eu)ago/ran.

The Teucridae ruled in Cyprus until a Phoenician exile seized the kingdom and subjected the whole island to the power of the King of Persia. When Evagoras was born, the descendants of the usurper still ruled.

ta\ u(pa/rcanta: u(pa/rxein has two main uses (1) ‘to begin’ usually with the genitive, sometimes absolutely as in § 28, (2) ‘to be in the beginning’ (so here ta\ u(pa/rcanta, ‘the original inheritance’), and so often merely ‘to be’, ‘to exist’, and followed by the dative ‘to belong to’.
thlikau=ta: thlikou=tos is here equivalent to tosou=tos; for another meaning see § 22.
to\ me/geqos, adverbial acc. qualifying thlikau=ta; cp. § 65 tosou=toi to\ plh=qos.

xro/nw| d' u(/steron, ‘some time afterwards’; cp. Lys. 3.39 xro/nois u(/steron. xro/nos can mean not only ‘time’, but also ‘a considerable period of time’; cp. Herodot. ix. 62 xro/nw| pote/, ‘at last.’
a)nh\r fuga/s: his name is not recorded.

pisteuqei/s: in Greek, unlike Latin, verbs which in the active govern a gen. or dat. can be used personally in the passive; cp. oi( a)rxo/menoi (N. C. 38), ‘subjects’ (lit. ‘those ruled’), from a)/rxw, which in the active governs a genitive.
deino\s de\ pro\s to\ pleonekth=sai: lit. ‘being terrible at seizing more than his share’, so ‘being exceedingly grasping’. For pleonekth=sai see note on § 11.
a)pistw=n toi=s pepragme/nois, ‘feeling doubtful about the result of his actions.’

e)cebarba/rwse: i. e. he ‘barbarized’ Cyprus by discouraging Greek influence and culture. To a Greek any one who was not a Greek was a barbarian, ba/rbaros being an onomatopoeic word signifying one who speaks an unintelligible language. The barbarization of Cyprus is more fully described in § 47. For the probable date and duration of this period of Phoenician influence in Cyprus see Introd. p. 18 f.

basilei= tw=| mega/lw|: basileu\s o( me/gas, and often basileu/s without the article (as in § 55, 57, 62, 68), always refers to the King of Persia as the foreign king with whom the Greeks had most concern.
e)kei/nou: i. e. the usurper.

gi/gnetai: Schneider quotes numerous passages illustrating the use of the historic present of gi/gnesqai in the sense of ‘to be born’, e.g. Herod. i. 102 *dhio/kew pai=s gi/gnetai *frao/rths; cp. Suet. Nero 4 ex hoc Domitius nascitur.
peri\ ou(=: for the hiatus cp. peri\ au(tw=n, § 3, and note.
fh/mas: frequently used of chance utterances interpreted as omens by those who heard them.
e)c w(=n meizo/nws kte(, ‘judging from which his birth would appear to have something superhuman about it.’
meizo/nws: see note on filotimote/rws, § 5. The forms meizo/nws and meio/nws are more usual in Attic Greek than mei=zon and mei=on.
h)\ kata/: the Latin quam pro; cp. N. C. 55 traxu/teron h)\ kata\ th\n au(tw=n gnw/mhn.

tosou/tou de/w: constructed with the infin. followed by w(/ste with the indic. (Latin, tantum absum ut . . . ut . . .). Only in this and similar phrases (e.g. mikrou= e)de/hse, § 62) is de/w used personally in
the active. tosou/tou is genitive after a verb expressing need or want.
tw=n u(parxo/ntwn: lit. ‘things existing’, so ‘actually true cases’ of omens, &c. For u(pa/rxein see note on § 19.
The youth of Evagoras gave promise of future greatness. The good qualities which he displayed when he reached manhood clearly showed that he was not destined to spend his life in a private station.
tw=n a)gaqw=n: partitive genitive, ‘among good qualities.’

toi=s thlikou/tois: thlikou=tos, lit. ‘of such a size’ (cp. § 19), often means ‘of that age’, so here ‘those of his own age’, i. e. boys; it can equally well mean ‘old men’, e.g. Panath. 88 toi=s thlikou/tois.

tw=n h(likiwtw=n: genitive after the superlative idea contained in e)krati/steusen . h(likiw/ths, ‘of a certain time of life,’ here ‘contemporaries’. h(liki/a means ‘any time of life’, especially ‘prime of life’, with reference to the age at which a man can serve as a soldier; but in § 71 it refers to ‘old age’, in N. C. 44, 45 to ‘youth’.
ou) me/sws, ‘to no ordinary degree’; cp. Thuc. vi. 54 me/sos poli/ths, ‘an ordinary citizen.’
e(te/rois: dat. after prosgi/gnetai understood.

yuxh=s: it is interesting to note the use of this word in Isocr. The chief uses of the word in Greek are: (1) ‘breath’, so ‘life’ (as in § 41, see note); (2) ‘the immortal part of man’, his ‘soul’; (3) ‘soul’ in sense of ‘reason’, ‘mind’, ‘intelligence’. It is used by Isocr. almost invariably in the last sense, the ‘mind’ as opposed to the body (so here and § 27; ad N. 11, 37, 46); in N. C. 59 it means an ‘attitude of mind’. It can even be used of animals, au)tw=n ta\s yuxa\s h(merou=men, ‘we tame their spirits’ (ad N. 12). In short, it is never used in a metaphysical sense. The only passage in these three speeches where it can be rendered ‘soul’ (=‘personality’) is N. C. 7 lo/gos a)lhqh\s kai\ no/mimos kai\ di/kaios yuxh=s a)gaqh=s kai\ pisth=s ei)/dwlo/n e)stin; but here the idea of the mental side of personality is uppermost.
u(perbolh/n: see note on § 1.
dih/negken: see note on § 14.
oi( to/te basileu/ontes: the reference must be to the usurper, and either the plur. is used for sing., or else it means the usurper and his family.
th\n fu/sin: adverbial acc. after toiou=ton; cp. § 19 thlikau=ta to\ me/geqos.

diagagei=n: sc., as often, to\n bi/on (which Isocr. inserts in N. C. 2 to\n bi/on dia/gwmen); cp. the similar omission of xro/non with diatri/bein in § 31, &c. (inserted in N. C. 19 xro/non diatri/bousin). For the literal sense of dia/gein, ‘lead through,’ cp. § 30 tou\s me/q' au(tou= diagagw/n.
a)poble/yeian: a)poble/pein, ‘to look away from (other things)’ ei)s, ‘at’, so ‘look (steadfastly) at’.
e)camarta/nein: lit. ‘to make a mistake’, so followed by peri/ and the acc., ‘to do wrong to.’
Heaven watched over Evagoras and helped him to win back the kingdom without committing impiety. A noble of Salamis murdered the usurper and attempted to seize Evagoras, who, however, escaped.

tosou=ton th=s do/chs kte(, ‘in spite of (two) such different opinions about him, they were not wrong in either case,’ lit. ‘though their opinion (about him) varied so much’ (i. e. in spite of their two very different opinions about him, namely, that (1) he was too able a man to remain in a private station, and (2) that he was always ready to help others) ‘they were not deceived in either’. paralla/ttein, a word not elsewhere found in Isocr., is here used intransitively.

o( dai/mwn: qeo/s means a particular god, dai/mwn, ‘divine power’, ‘potency’. dai/mwn often means a ‘genius’, i.e. the power that watches over an individual, so ‘lot’, ‘fortune’. Here perhaps we may translate ‘Heaven watched over him’, &c.

e)/sxen au)tou= pro/noian o(/pws lh/yetai: the future indic. is used with o(/pws after verbs of taking care and striving, even though the principal verb is historic, because the mood and tense are retained which would be used when the person conceived the purpose; cp. the retention of original tenses in reported speech.
kalw=s, ‘honourably.’

e)c w(=n d' oi(=o/n t) h)=n kte(: the subject of diefu/lacen is o( dai/mwn understood, and the object is an antecedent supplied from e)c w(=n
(cp. a)feme/nous e)f' oi(=s, § 78). Translate: ‘but reserved for Evagoras the means whereby it was possible for him to win the kingdom righteously and justly.’

ei(=s ga\r tw=n dunasteuo/ntwn, ‘one of the powerful men of Salamis,’ by name Abdemon, who, according to Diodorus (xiv. 98), was a native of Citium in Cyprus, but, according to Theopompus (fr. 111), a Tyrian.
sullabei=n: sullamba/nein is regularly used as a technical legal term, ‘to arrest.’
e)kpodw/n: an adverb, ‘out of the way’ (e)k, pou/s).

Evagoras escaped from Cyprus to Soli in Cilicia. At a moment when he might well have been in despair, he conceived the idea of regaining the lost throne of his forefathers. He gathered fifty devoted adherents and returned to Salamis.

*so/lous: Soli was an Athenian colony south-west of Tarsus in Cilicia. It must be distinguished from Soli in the north-west of Cyprus, which was a Phoenician settlement. Strabo (p. 663) derived the word so/loikos, ‘speaking incorrectly,’ and soloikismo/s (our English word ‘solecism’), from the fact that the Attic dialect became corrupt among the colonists of Soli; this derivation is, however, improbable.
th\n au)th\n gnw/mhn toi=s . . . peripi/ptousi: o( au)to/s is regularly followed by the dative, ‘the same as,’ cp. § 77 tw=n au)tw=n e)kei/nois e)pithdeuma/twn e)piqumw=sin.
tapeinote/ras, ‘humbled,’ lit. ‘more humble (i.e. than usual)’.
ei)s tosou=ton megalofrosu/nhs, ‘to such (a point of) greatness of soul’; for the neuter of the pronoun followed by the genitive cp. § 54 ei)s tou=t' a)plhsti/as.
to\n a)/llon xro/non: a)/llos when applied to xro/nos almost always refers to the past, loipo/s (§ 80) or e)pi/loipos (N. C. 58) being used of the future.
w)/n: the present participle often serves as an imperfect participle, trans. ‘though he had been’.
pla/nous tou\s fugadikou\s kte(, ‘he despised a wandering life of exile, and the attempt to obtain his release by the help of others, and courting men who were his inferiors.’
ka/qodon: the regular word for ‘return’ from exile; the verb is katelqei=n, § 36.

qerapeu/ein: lit. ‘to pay attention to’, esp. of the gods, ‘to worship’ (cp. qerapei/a, ad N. 20); of human beings, ‘to court’, ‘pay attention to’, so (ad N. 28) ‘to serve’ (cp. qerapei/a (N. C. 22) ‘service’, (§ 46) ‘devotion to’); ‘to win over’ (ad N. 16), ‘to make much of’ (ad N. 53); but here in a bad sense ‘to flatter’. It is also used as a medical technical term to ‘treat’, ‘attend’.

labw\n de\ tau/thn a)formh/n, ‘taking this as his principle.’ tau/thn, in the absence of the definite article, must be predicative. a)formh/, lit. ‘starting-point’, so ‘principle’; it can also be used as a military term ‘base of operations’, and by a slight extension of meaning ‘resources’, ‘advantages’ (as in ad N. 4).
xrh/: sc. labei=n.

a)mu/nesqai kai\ mh\ prote/rous u(pa/rxein, ‘to act on the defensive and not to begin a quarrel’; cp. de bigis 44 ou)d' a)muno/menos a)ll) u(pa/rxwn h)di/keis au)tou/s. For u(pa/rxein see note on § 19. prote/rous is pleonastic.

parakale/sas, ‘having called in the help of’; a more common meaning of parakalei=n is ‘to exhort’, followed by e)pi/ or pro/s, or the acc. and infin., cp. N. C. 12 parakale/sai pro\s to\ mnhmoneu/ein.

w(s oi( tou\s plei/stous le/gontes: sc. le/gousi, ‘according to the account of those who give the highest estimate.’ For the ellipse, Schneider compares Plut. Cleom. 9. 3 dio\ kai\ kalw=s o( ei)pw/n (sc. ei)=pen), *(/ina ga\r de/os, e)/nqa kai\ ai)dw/s.

me/llontos . . . ou)/t' e)kei=nos h)qu/mhsen: the gen. abs. is generally used only when the participle cannot agree with some substantive in the sentence. This rule, however, is violated in order to emphasize the participial clause. Here me/llontos might have been nominative agreeing with e)kei=nos: the gen. abs. may be justified on the ground that there are two alternative principal clauses, ou)/t' e)kei=nos h)qu/mhse and ou)/te . . . ou)dei\s . . . h)ci/wsen, and of the two subjects e)kei=nos only refers to the same person as me/llontos. Other examples are Xen. Cyrop. i. 4. § 2 kai\ ga\r a)sqenh/santos au)tou= ou)de/pote a)pe/leipe to\n pa/ppon, and Plato, Rep. 547^{b} biazome/nwn de\ kai\ a)nteino/ntwn a)llh/lois . . . w(molo/ghsan.
tosou/twn, ‘so few men.’ The meaning of tosou=tos, like that of thlikou=tos (see note on § 22), depends on the context.
to\ me/geqos: see note on § 19.
tw=n paraklhqe/ntwn, ‘those whom he had summoned to his aid’; cp. parakale/sas, § 28 and note.
w(/sper . . . ou(/tw die/keito th\n gnw/mhn, ‘showed the determination of one who’ &c., lit. ‘was so disposed as to his mind as though’.

Without attempting to occupy a strong position Evagoras broke open a gate of the city and marched on the palace. After a desperate struggle he captured it, secured the city and established himself on his ancestral throne.
dh=lon d' e)k tw=n e)/rgwn: a)poba\s ga/r: for the omission of the copula and the use of ga/r cp. § 8 shmei=on de\ me/giston and note.

periidei=n, ei), ‘wait and see whether,’ lit. ‘look around to see if’. periora=n is much more frequently used in the sense of to ‘overlook’, i. e. ‘look on without noticing’, so ‘allow’, ‘suffer’, followed by the acc. of the participle; cp. ad N. 16 h)\n mh/q' u(bri/zein to\n o)/xlon e)a=|s mh/q) u(brizo/menon periora=|s.
w(/sper ei)=xe, ‘as he was.’ e)/xw is frequently used as an auxiliary with adverbs (cp. § 49 a)prosoi/stws kai\ xalepw=s ei)=xon, &c.) and, as here, with adverbial conjunctions.
diagagw/n: see note on § 24 for the meaning of dia/gein.
kairoi=s: kairo/s means ‘time’ in the sense of ‘a point of time’, so ‘moment’, ‘opportunity’, ‘crisis’; xro/nos is ‘time’ in general or ‘period of time’ (see also note on § 19).

diatri/bein: sc. to\n xro/non, see note on § 24 diagagei=n. diatri/bein is lit. ‘to rub away’ (cp. Latin tempus terere), so with to\n xro/non ‘to spend time’, so ‘live’, sometimes in a bad sense ‘to waste time’. The substantive diatribh/ means (1) ‘spending time’, so ‘pastime’ (‘pass-time’), ‘amusement’, ‘society’ (as in ad N. 29); (2) ‘serious employment’, ‘study’ (as in § 78, N. C. 1); so (3) ‘discussion’, ‘conversation’ (as in § 74); (4) ‘waste of time’.
a)ntagwnistw=n . . . qeatw=n: predicative, ‘while the followers of the tyrant resisted him and the rest of the citizens looked on.’
tou= me/n: the tyrant. tou= de/: Evagoras.
kai\ mo/nos pro\s pollou\s kai\ met' o)li/gwn pro\s a(/pantas tou\s e)xqrou/s: a good example of chiasmus. We should translate ‘either singlehanded . . . or with a small band of men’.

The story of his recovery of the kingdom is enough to show how great a man Evagoras was. His greatness can be further illustrated by comparing his achievements with those of the famous men of history.
ou) mh\n a)lla/: elliptical, ‘not indeed . . . but,’ so ‘nevertheless’; cp. the colloquial English, ‘not but what.’

e)k tw=n e)xome/nwn, ‘from what follows’. e)/xesqai is lit. ‘to hold for oneself’, so ‘to cling to’, so ‘to be near’ (cp. oi( e)xo/menoi, ‘the neighbours,’ and Paneg. 96 th\n e)xome/nhn nh=son), so ‘to follow’ (cp. Thuc. vi. 3 to\ e)xo/menon e)/tos, ‘next year’); cp. to\n d' e)xo/menon (lo/gon), N. C. 11 and note.

pro\s e(/kaston au)tw=n: for pro\s ta\s e(ka/stou au)tw=n pra/ceis by a common Greek idiom in which a quality is compared, not with another quality, but with the possessor of that quality; cp. Hom. Il. xvii. 51 ko/mai *xari/tessin o(moi=ai, ‘hair like (that of) the Graces,’ and ad N. 31 to\ th=s po/lews o(/lhs h)=qos o(moiou=tai toi=s a)/rxousin.
ou)/t' a)\n o( lo/gos kte(., ‘such a detailed account would not perhaps suit the occasion, nor would the time suffice for its recital.’
kairoi=s . . . xro/nos: see note on § 31.
e)pi\ tou/twn skopw=men, ‘we test Evagoras by the light of them.’ For this use of e)pi/ cp. ad N. 50 e)pi\ tw=n xrhsi/mwn au)tou\s dokima/zein.

e)cetw=men: contracted for the more common e)ceta/somen; cp. bibw=n (fut. part.) from biba/zw (Soph. O. C. 381). This so-called Attic future is most frequently found in verbs in -i/zw, e.g. komi/zw, fut. komiw=. s has a strong tendency to drop out between two vowels.

How far more glorious to win a throne, as Evagoras did, than to inherit it! The poets tell us of early heroes who recovered their kingdoms, even inventing such stories; but no poet ever imagined such dangers as Evagoras underwent or such honourable methods as he adopted.

tw=n me
 ou)=n kte(, ‘who would not prefer the dangers of Evagoras to the lot of those who inherit kingdoms from their forefathers?’ tw=n ... paralabo/ntwn is equivalent to tw=n pragma/twn tw=n . . . paralabo/ntwn, see note on § 34 pro\s e(/kaston au)tw=n. paralamba/nein has a slightly different sense in § 47 paralabw
 th
 po/lin, ‘when he took over the government,’ and in N. C. 28 where paralabw/n means
‘taking along with him’. tw=n paralabo/ntwn is gen. after the comparative idea contained in prokri/neien.

r(a/|qumos: lit. (r(a/|dios qumo/s) ‘easy in mind’. The meaning depends on the context; here, Clarke well translates ‘indifferent to fame’. It can be used in a good sense ‘free from anxiety’ (cp. § 42 r(a|qumiw=n); or in a bad sense ‘idle’ (cp. § 45 r(a|qumi/as, and § 75 and ad N. 10 r(a|qumei=n).

ou(/tw r(a/|qumos o(/stis: the relative (o(/s or o(/stis) in Greek can be used like the Latin qui to introduce a consecutive clause; cp. § 80 toiau=ta kai\ le/gein kai\ gra/fein, e)c w(=n me/llome/n se parocu/nein.
kaqo/dwn: see note on § 28.
par' au(tw=n kaina\s suntiqe/asin, ‘invent imaginary instances out of their own heads.’
o(/stis: an antecedent, such as ti/na or ou)de/na, must be supplied as the object of memuqolo/ghken; cp. § 26 e)c w(=n d' oi(=o/n t) h)=n kte(. and note.

poihsa/menos . . . pepoi/hntai: the o(mwnumi/a or play on the two meanings of poiei=n (1) to ‘do’, (2) to ‘compose poetry’, cannot be kept up in English. Sandys, on Paneg. 186, quotes Plato, Lysis 206 B sko/pei . . . o(/pws mh\ pa=si tou/tois e)/noxon sauto\n poih/sh|s dia\ th\n poi/hsin, and Ben Jonson, Trans. of Horace, Ars Poetica 317 And I shall bid the learned maker (i. e. poet) looke On life and manners and make these his book. Similar plays on words are found with a)rxh/ (N. C. 28, Paneg. 119), ai)ti/a (Ep. vi. 3), lo/gos (Panath. 22), xa/ris (Ep. ii. 6). Here poihsa/menos means ‘having brought upon himself’, lit. ‘having made for himself’; pepoi/hntai, ‘are represented’ (by the poets), cp. poih=sai, § 9.
ei)s th\n au(tou=: sc. gh=n.

perigegenhme/noi tw=n e)xqrw=n, ‘getting the better of their enemies.’ Verbs of ruling, conquering (a)/rxein, kratei=n, basileu/ein, &c.), and leading (h(gei=sqai) take a genitive. perigi/gnesqai means either (1) ‘to be superior to’, with an object in the gen. (as here and § 44), or, absolutely, ‘to be victorious’ (as in § 55 and ad N. 25); or (2) ‘to live beyond’, so ‘survive’.

p.title: In historical times Cyrus is the most famous example of a king who won a kingdom; but, in the first place, he had a large army of Persians, while Evagoras conquered by his personal valour, and, secondly, Cyrus was less particular in the means which he em-
p.hi: ployed. In fact, no mortal or immortal hero ever acquired a throne so honourably as Evagoras.

div2.p: e)pi\ ta/de, ‘nearer our own day,’ i. e. living in historical times as opposed to the mythical heroes of the poets. e)pi\ ta/de is the opposite of e)pe/keina, § 6 and note.

to\n *mh/dwn a)felo/menon th\n a)rxh/n, ‘who deprived the Medes of their kingdom’ in 559 B.C. Three constructions are found with a)fairei=sqai: (1) (most commonly) double acc. of person and thing; (2) acc. of the thing and dat. of the person; (3) (as here) acc. of the thing and gen. of the person.
kai\ plei=stoi kai\ ma/lista: for this union of an adj. and an adv. Schneider compares N. C. 13 e)/xw th\n a)rxh\n ou) parano/mws ou)d' a)llotri/an, and ib. 47 e(ko/ntas kai\ proqu/mws.

dia\ th=s yuxh=s th=s au(tou= kai\ tou= sw/matos . . . diapraca/menos: this appears to be a more emphatic periphrasis for the common di) au(tou= pra/ttein ti, ‘to do something by one's self, unassisted’; trans. ‘by his own spirit and in his own person’. For yuxh/ in Isocr. see note on § 23.
tw=n proeirhme/nwn, ‘the achievements which we have described.’
ou)/pw dh=lon: lit. ‘not yet clear’, we should say ‘not quite clear’.
tw=n tou/tw| pepragme/nwn: the dat. of the agent; cp. e)kei/nw| (§ 2 and note), and below, tw=| me\n . . . pe/praktai.

to\n pate/ra to\n th=s mhtro/s: Astyages whose daughter Mandane married Cambyses, father of Cyrus. No other writer tells us that Cyrus put Astyages to death; on the contrary according to Herod. (i. 130), ‘Cyrus did no harm to Astyages but kept him with him until he died.’

mhde\n u(posteila/menon, ‘without any reservations.’ The metaphor is originally a nautical one, u(poste/llesqai ta\ i(sti/a, ‘to furl the sails.’ It is noticeable that the metaphors used by a nation are generally taken from their characteristic pursuits: in the Attic writers they are usually nautical, gymnastic, or legal.
e)kei/nws . . . ei), ‘(in the following way) . . . if’; cp. § 11 e)kei=qen and note.
e)tura/nneusen, ‘came to the throne’; the so-called ‘ingressive’ aorist.
mega/la le/gein, ‘to exaggerate’; cp. § 48 mei/zw le/gein.

e)k panto\s tro/pou, ‘recklessly,’ lit. ‘by any means (I can)’, similarly used in N. C. 31; pa=s from meaning ‘every’ often comes to mean ‘any’, cp. panou=rgos, ‘a scoundrel,’ lit. ‘one who will do everything’ so ‘anything’.
ou(/tw: qualifies qrase/ws, its position is probably due to a desire to avoid the hiatus which would be caused if it immediately preceded qrase/ws.

If Evagoras had gained distinction by less important achievements, he would yet have deserved praise; but as it is, no poet or orator could adequately extol him. Naturally gifted he left nothing to chance, but always acted with deliberation.
e)pi\ mikroi=s, ‘in unimportant achievements.’
dih/negke: used absolutely, ‘had distinguished himself’; see note on § 14.
nu=n de/, ‘but as it is.’
a)gaqw=n: used as a substantive, ‘blessings’; cp. Latin summum bonum.

semno/taton: semno/s, originally of the gods, ‘revered’, solemn’, so of human beings and qualities: (1) in a good sense, ‘august’, ‘dignified’ (as here and § 44 and ad N. 34); (2) in a bad sense, ‘pompous’, ‘proud’. In N.C. 42 semno/teros is opposed to tapeino/teros and means ‘of higher birth’. The verb semnu/nesqai has similar meanings (ad N. 34 tou\s semnunome/nous, ‘those who are dignified’; but semnu/nesqai e)pi/ (§ 74), ‘to pride oneself on’).

lo/gwn eu(reth/s: the same expression is found in Philip. 144 th\n *eu)rusqe/ws du/namin ou)dei\s a)\n ou)/te lo/gwn eu(reth\s ou)/te poihth\s e)paine/seien. eu(reth/s is used in the sense of ‘deviser’, cp. ad N. 17 eu(reth\s gi/gnou tw=n belti/stwn (e)pithdeuma/twn); lo/gwn is used in the sense of discourse as in § 4. The whole phrase means ‘composers of set discourses’, such as the Busiris and Helen of Isocrates. It was the regular practice of the Sophists, the professional teachers of rhetoric, to deliver such declamations (e)pidei/ceis) on subjects taken from the Epic poets or from mythology. See Jebb, Attic Orators, ii. 93 ff.
a)ci/ws tw=n pepragme/nwn: see note on § 2.
ou): negatives both the verb and the participle.
u(perballo/menos: absolutely, ‘excelled,’ see note on § 1 u(perbolh/n.
eu)fue/statos w)\n th\n gnw/mhn, ‘naturally gifted with the highest intelligence.’
plei=sta katorqou=n duna/menos, ‘able generally to command success.’
o)ligwrei=n: here used absolutely, ‘to act rashly’ (so in Areop. 46); it is more commonly found with a genitive meaning ‘to despise’, ‘overlook’ (N. C. 18, 48).
au)tosxedia/zein: (sxe/dios, ‘offhand’), ‘to act on the spur of the moment.’
ei) kalw=s . . . paraskeua/seie, ‘if he ordered his own intellect aright.’
qauma/zwn d' o(/soi: an antecedent such as e)kei/nous must be understood as object of qauma/zwn; cp. § 26 e)c w(=n d' oi(=o/n t) h)=n kte(. and note.
tw=n a)/llwn: objective gen. after e)pime/leian, ‘care about everything else.’

e(/neka th=s yuxh=s: e(/neka more frequently follows the word which it governs. For the meaning of yuxh/ in Isocr. see note on § 23. As Schneider points out yuxh=s must here mean ‘life’; but in au)th=s tau/ths which is used to avoid a repetition of yuxh=s, another aspect of yuxh/, namely, ‘the mind,’ is predominant; we must use different words in English to make the meaning clear.

His energy, impartiality, and humanity were the admiration of all who visited Cyprus during his reign. He was just and consistent and never spared himself in the service of the state; in short, he possessed the ideal qualifications not only of a monarch, but also of a popular leader, an administrator, and a general.

tw=n pragma/twn: the ‘events’ of daily life. Isocr. now turns from describing the qualities which Evagoras displayed when he won the kingdom to those which marked the fulfilment of his duties as king.
tw=n o)/ntwn: can only mean ‘the facts of life’; Blass suggests tw=n paro/ntwn, ‘the circumstances before them,’ which gives a clearer sense.
r(a|qumiw=n . . . a)rgi/ais . . . eu)pragi/ais: for these plurals cp. tai=s a)lhqei/ais, § 5 and note.
r(a|qumiw=n: see note on r(a/|qumos, § 35.

fqa/nein: lit. ‘overtake’, ‘anticipate’; it is here used absolutely ‘to take unawares’ (it is similarly coupled with lanqa/nein in N. C. 22,
where see note). It is frequently constructed with a participle (e.g. Paneg. 79 fqh/sontai th\n po/lin a)gaqo/n ti poih/santes, ‘they will be the first to benefit the city’). For ou) fqa/nein and a participle followed by kai/ see § 53.

mh/te . . . lanqa/nein, ‘were well known to him.’ lanqa/nein, lit. ‘escape notice’, is used either absolutely (as here and N. C. 22), or followed by the acc. ‘to be unnoticed by some one’ (as in 78 ou) ga\r e)me\ le/lhqas, o(/ti, ‘I did not fail to notice that you,’ &c., and N. C. 51 h(gei/sqw mhd' e)me\ lh/sein, ‘remember that it will not escape my notice either’), or with participle (as in N. C. 41 lanqa/nousin . . . diafora\s e)gkatalei/pontes, lit. ‘escape notice storing up quarrels for themselves’, i. e. ‘are unawares storing up strife’). lanqa/nesqai (middle) means ‘to forget’ (followed by the gen.).
e)c w(=n: relatival attraction for e)c e)kei/nwn a(/. e(te/rwn is gen. of the person after h)/kouen, ‘from others.’
au(to\n katasth/sas, ‘having established himself in,’ so ‘having engaged himself in’.

ou)de\ peri\ tw=n . . . ou)de\ peri\ e(/n: the first ou)de/ goes with the whole sentence, the second goes closely with the e(/n (ou)de\ peri\ e(/n being a more emphatic form of peri\ ou)de/n). For the hiatus see note on § 3. peri/ with the genitive ‘concerning’, with the acc. ‘in the case of’.

peplanhme/nws ei)=xen, ‘made a mistake’; for the use of e)/xw see note on w(/sper ei)=xen, § 30. For adverbs formed from participles cp. o(mologoume/nws (§ 67), a)proxrw/ntws, proshko/ntws (N. C. 27), e)rrwmeneste/rws (ad N. 14), prepo/ntws (Panath. 31), &c.

tou\s ei)safiknoume/nous, ‘visitors to the island.’ We are told (§ 51 and note) that a number of Greeks took up their abode in Cyprus. Andocides the orator visited the island about 410 B.C., when Evagoras had probably recently become king; he presumably was not among those who spoke with enthusiasm of Evagoras' rule, for he was thrown into prison for a crime committed there ([Lysias], contra Andoc. 28 ff.).

mh\ ma=llon . . . h)/, ‘not more than,’ i. e. ‘not so much . . . as’; ‘did not so much envy Evagoras for being king as his subjects for being ruled by him’ (tou\s a)/llous=tou\s a)rxome/nous, which, indeed, is read by Stobaeus (Flor. 48, 50) who quotes the passage); cp. N. C. 55 qarrei=te mh\ ma=llon dia\ th

*eu)ago/ran th=s a)rxh=s zhlou=n: zhlou=n is regularly constructed with the acc. of the person and the (causal) gen. of the thing; similarly qauma/zein, oi)ktei/rein, fqonei=n, stugei=n, and other verbs expressing emotion; cp. Soph. El. 1027 zhlw= se tou= nou=, th=s de\ deili/as stugw=.

th=s u(p' e)kei/nou basilei/as: u(po/ with the gen. can be used to denote the agent with a substantive which has a passive significance. Schneider quotes Thuc. ii. 65 lo/gw| me\n dhmokrati/a, e)/rgw| de\ u(po\ tou= prw/tou a)ndro\s a)rxh/.

tw=n xrwme/nwn, ‘his intimate friends.’ xrh=sqai (like the Latin uti) originally means ‘to be in a certain relation to’, so ‘to have to do with’, so here ‘to treat as a friend’; cp. ad Demon. 20 xrw= toi=s belti/stois and ad N. 27 toi=s xrwme/nois.
h(ttw/menos, ‘being inferior to’, so ‘being conquered by’, translate ‘giving way to’; cp. tw=n e)piqumiw=n h(ttwme/nous, N. C. 39.
tw=n e)xqrw=n perigigno/menos: see note on § 36.
semno/s: see note on § 40.

tai=s tou= prosw/pou sunagwgai=s: lit. ‘by drawings together of his face’, so ‘knitting the brows’. kataskeuai=s: the usual meaning of kataskeuh/ is ‘furniture’, ‘apparatus’, ‘equipment’ (cp. ad N. 19), esp. in the sense of ‘buildings’, ‘fixtures’ (cp. § 47 and note), hence ‘fundamental principle’; here it means ‘arrangement’, ‘method’, cp. Plato, Legg. 736 B politikh\ kataskeuh/. Freese translates, ‘showing his dignity, not by knitted brows, but by his manner of life.’
ou)de\ pro\s e(/n: a stronger form of pro\s ou)de/n; cp. ou)de\ peri\ e(/n, § 43.
a)ta/ktws ou)d' a)nwma/lws diakei/menos: lit. ‘irregularly or unevenly disposed’, i.e. ‘behaving capriciously or inconsistently’. For a)nwma/lws cp. a)nwmali/as (ad N. 6).

o(moi/ws ta\s e)n toi=s e)/rgois o(mologi/as kte(, ‘preserving consistency, alike in word and deed.’ The commonest meaning of o(mologi/a is ‘agreement’ (in the sense of ‘assent’ and ‘compact’), ‘admission’, ‘confession’. Here ta\s e)n toi=s e)/rgois o(mologi/as means that his acts agreed with one another, i.e. were consistent with one another; compare the use of the verb o(mologei=n in ad N. 17 sfi/sin au)toi=s o(mologoume/nous, ‘consistent with one another.’
me/ga fronw=n . . . e)pi/, ‘priding himself on’; cp. semnu/nesqai e)pi/ (§ 74).
u(f' au(tw=| poiou/menos, ‘attaching to himself.’
tw=| polloi=s xalepai/nein, ‘by a frequent display of harshness,’ lit. ‘by being harsh to many’.
u(perba/llein: see note on u(perbolh/n, § 1.

h(gou/menos tw=n h(donw=n, ‘controlling his pleasures,’ lit. ‘leading’. h(gei=sqai like the Latin ducere means (1) to ‘lead’, in which case it is followed by a genitive, or dative when used of an army or fleet (never in Isocrates); (2) ‘to consider’ (often followed by double accusative, as in ad N. 25, 28, &c., N. C. 10, 58).
r(a|qumi/as: see note on r(a/|qumos, § 35.
w(=n: relatival attraction for e)kei/nwn a(/, see note on h(=s (§ 11).
w(=n prosei=nai dei=: lit. ‘of those things which ought to attach to’, so ‘of the proper qualities of’.

e(ka/sths th=s politei/as, ‘every kind of political activity’ (Clarke). politei/a means originally ‘the condition of a citizen’, so (1) the duties of a citizen (N. C. 10) ‘political activity’ (as here), ‘political power’ (§ 66), ‘political rights’ (N. C. 15), ‘statesmanship’ (cp. the use of politiko/s, below); (2) ‘form of government’, ‘constitution’ (§ 51, ad N. 8, 16, N. C. 12, 14, 16, 22, &c.).

dhmotiko\s . . . politiko\s . . . strathgiko\s . . . turanniko/s. The termination -iko/s implies ‘fitness’ or ‘capability’; trans. ‘popular leader . . . capable administrator . . . able general . . . ideal monarch’.
qerapei/a|, ‘devotion to’; see note on qerapeu/ein, § 28.
politiko/s: see note on § 10.

turanniko/s: for the reading see critical note. It is hardly conceivable that Isocrates wrote dhmotiko\s . . . politiko\s . . . strathgiko\s . . . megalo/frwn. tu/rannos is not necessarily a term of reproach, but merely means an ‘unconstitutional monarch’; so turanniko/s here is used in a good sense; cp. ad N. 53, where it means ‘princely’, ‘royal’.
diafe/rein: used absolutely, see note on dih/negken, § 14.
prosh=n: see above w(=n prosei=nai dei=.

p.title: Evagoras found the city completely barbarized, without arts or commerce; he built new fortifications and public buildings, and constructed ships. In particular, he introduced Greek culture, which quickly took root and flourished; numerous Greeks settled in
p.hi: the island, whereas under Phoenician influence no intercourse with Greece had been allowed.

div2.p: paralabw/n: see note on § 35.
dia\ th\n *foini/kwn a)rxh/n: for Phoenician influence in Cyprus see Introd. p. 18.
prosekth/sato . . . prosperieba/leto: note the force of pro/s in composition with verbs, ‘he acquired much fresh territory . . . he had new walls built.’

trih/reis e)nauphgh/sato: the force of nau/s in e)nauphgh/sato is redundant; Schneider compares ne/ktar oi)noxoei=n (Hom. Il. iv. 3) and— a still more striking example—boukolei=n i(/ppous (ib. xx. 221).
tai=s a)/llais kataskeuai=s: kataskeuai/ (see note on § 44) applied to a city means ‘equipment’; the reference here is probably to theatres, gymnasia, public baths built by Evagoras.
a)polelei=fqai: see note on § 18 ou)deno\s . . . a)poleifqe/ntos.
thlikau/tas: see notes on § 19 and 22.
e)pido/seis: see note on § 7.
h)/qesin: h)/qh from meaning ‘customs’ comes to mean, as here, ‘characteristics’, ‘qualities’, of an individual.
oi(/ois: the relative is attracted from the acc. (oi(=a) to the case of the antecedent; cp. h(=s (§ 11) and w(=n (§ 46) and notes.
pro/teron: i.e. in § 22-4.
mei/zw le/gwn: cp. mega/la le/gein, § 39.
dielqei=n: cp. § 12 note.
polu\ li/an a)poleifqw=: the more natural order would be li/an polu/, but this would cause a hiatus.
a)poleifqw=: see note on § 18 ou)deno\s . . . a)poleifqe/ntos.
tw=n pepragme/nwn au)tw=|: for the dative see note on § 2 e)kei/nw|.

e)fi/koito, ‘reach to,’ so ‘adequately describe’, ‘do justice to’; cp. Paneg. 187 to/te me\n ga\r w)/|mhn a)ci/ws dunh/sesqai tw=n pragma/twn ei)pei=n: nu=n d' ou)k e)fiknou=mai tou= mege/qous au)tw=n, ‘I thought then that I should be able to speak in a manner worthy of my subject; but now I cannot do justice to its importance.’ Jebb compares the use of the Latin consequi.
fu/sews: here of ‘natural qualities’, ‘character’, ‘talents’.
o(/s: an antecedent such as au)tou= must be supplied. o(/s is here causal ‘in as much as he’ (Latin quippe qui).

 nh=son: i. e. the mainland of Cilicia and Lycia and possibly Phoenicia. Some editors (see critical note) omit th
 nh=son, in which case the phrase will mean the districts of Cyprus round Salamis; this is, however, unnecessary, and the words are a characteristic exaggeration on the part of the author. With the exception of a few colonies, Greek influence in south-eastern Asia Minor was very slight until the time of Alexander the Great.

a)prosoi/stws kai\ xalepw=s ei)=xon, ‘were unsociable and intractable’; the Scholiast paraphrases, mh\ prosdexo/menoi/ tinas tw=n *(ellh/nwn. For e)/xein with an adverb see note on w(/sper ei)=xe, § 30.

metapeptw/kasin, ‘they are so entirely changed.’ meta/ when compounded with a verb implies either (1) ‘change’ as here and in metalla/ttein (§ 15); (2) ‘pursuit’, as in metape/mpesqai (ad N. 13), ‘to send to fetch’ (from the meaning of meta/ with the acc. ‘after’). metapi/ptein implies violent change.
oi(/tines . . . do/cousi: indirect question depending on a(milla=sqai.
kth/masi, ‘possessions,’ in particular ‘works of art’.
tw=n peri\ th\n mousikh/n: cp. § 1 and 4 notes. mousikh/ is here used in its widest sense to include literature and art.
diatri/bein, ‘live’; see note on § 31.

h)\ par' oi(=s pro/teron ei)wqo/tes h)=san: sc. diatri/bein, par' oi(=s for par' e)kei/nois par) oi(=s; ‘more men interested in literature and culture in general live in these parts than in the communities in which they formerly used to dwell,’ i. e. in the old centres of Greek culture,—an intolerable exaggeration on the part of Isocrates.

Many Greeks showed their appreciation of Evagoras by settling in Cyprus. Conon, in particular, after his defeat at Aegospotami sought his assistance. When the Spartans sent Agesilaus to Asia, Conon and Evagoras co-operated with the Persian commander Pharnabazus and defeated the Spartans at Cnidus. The result was that Greece was freed and Athens again became head of a maritime league.
me/giston de\ tekmh/rion . . . tw=n ga\r *(ellh/nwn: see note on shmei=on de\ me/giston, § 8.

kai\ tou= tro/pou kai\ th=s o(sio/thtos, ‘both of his general character and of his uprightness.’ The o(sio/ths is part of the tro/pos: Schneider
compares Plut. Timol. 31 poih/mata gra/fein kai\ tragw|di/as, ‘to write poems including tragedies,’ and the Homeric *trw=e/s te kai\ *(/ektwr.

kaloi\ ka)gaqoi/, ‘worthy citizens.’ kalo\s ka)gaqo/s was originally a distinctive class-name meaning ‘a man of noble birth’ (cp. Old French prud'homme); but later it came to mean one possessing the ideal qualities of a citizen, almost equivalent to the English ‘gentleman’. kalo/s, originally applied to beauty of outward form, comes to be used also of moral beauty, to\ kalo/n being equivalent to the Latin honestum; it was the aesthetic aspect of morality which especially appealed to the Greeks.

ta\s au(tw=n patri/das a)polipo/ntes: when the Thirty Tyrants gained the upper hand in Athens and falsely accused their opponents and confiscated their property, many of the better citizens fled for their lives; in other cities too the Spartans set up oligarchical government, and citizens who had leanings towards Athens and democracy went into exile.
politeiw=n: see note on § 46.
polu\ a)/n: with this conjunction of words Isocrates habitually admits a hiatus; cp. § 65.
*ko/nwna . . . ti/s ou)k oi)=den, o(/ti: for this construction cp. § 6 ou(\s ou)k i)/sasin ei), and note.
dustuxhsa/shs th=s po/lews: see critical note. The reference is to the defeat of the Athenians under Conon by the Spartans under Lysander at Aegospotami on the Hellespont in 405 B.C.
e)kleca/menos: sc. au)to/n from w(s *eu)ago/ran.
a)\n . . . gene/sqai: Conon's actual thought, ta/xista a)\n *eu)ago/ras ge/noito bohqo/s, is thrown into an indirect form after nomi/sas, ge/noito becoming infin. and the a)/n being retained.
ou)de\ peri\ e(no/s: a more emphatic form of peri\ ou)deno/s; cp. ou)de\ pro\s e(/n, § 44. For the hiatus after peri/ cp. peri\ au(tw=n, § 3 and note.
sune/bh ga\r au)tw=| kte(, ‘for the result of his arrival in Cyprus was that . . .’

ou)k e)/fqasan a)llh/lois plhsia/santes kai/, ‘they no sooner met one another than . . .’ For fqa/nein see note on § 42. ou) fqa/nein with a participle followed by kai/ and a verb in the indicative is used to express two actions following closely upon one another; cp. Paneg. 86 ou)k e)/fqasan puqo/menoi to

sfa=s au)tou/s: reflexive pronouns in Greek are used sometimes in place of reciprocal pronouns; cp. § 57 sfw=n au)tw=n, and ad N. 17 sfi/sin au)toi=s. se is used similarly in Latin.

mega/lh| metabolh=| kexrhme/nhn, ‘had undergone a great change.’ xrh=sqai (like uti in Latin) means originally ‘to be in a certain relation to’ (see § 44), so either (1) in a good sense, ‘to enjoy,’ cp. xrh=sqai galanei/a| (Eur. I. A. 546), ‘to enjoy calm weather’; or (2) in a bad sense ‘to suffer’, cp. dustuxi/a| xrh=sqai.
a)mfo/teroi prosh/konta poiou=ntes: lit. ‘both doing what was fitting’, so ‘both of them with good cause’.
fu/sei, ‘by birth,’ as in § 12.

to\n de\ . . . poli/thn e)pepoi/hnto: the conferment of Athenian citizenship upon Evagoras is alluded to by Demosthenes (xii. 10) u(mei=s e)/dote politei/an *eu)ago/ra| tw=| *kupri/w| kai\ *dionusi/w| tw=| *surakosi/w| kai\ toi=s e)kgo/nois toi=s e)kei/nwn.
no/mw|: in Greek no/mos is continually contrasted with fu/sis.
skopoume/nois . . . o(/pws . . . a)palla/cousi: see note on § 25 e)/sxen au)tou= pro/noian o(/pws lh/yetai.
taxu/n: predicative.
ei)s tou=t' a)plhsti/as: cp. § 27 ei)s tosou=ton megalofrosu/nhs and note.
e)pexei/rhsan: under the command of Agesilaus, King of Sparta.
basile/ws: for the omission of the article see note on § 20. The King of Persia referred to is Artaxerxes II (Mnemon), who ruled from 404-361 B. C.
o(/ ti xrh/swntai toi=s pra/gmasi: deliberative subjunctive, ‘how to deal with the situation.’
perige/nointo: see note on § 36.
th\n h)/peiron: i.e. Asia Minor. Schneider quotes Harpocration p. 93 (Bekker) to show that Isocr. regularly uses h)/peiros to denote the territory of the King of Persia.

katenaumaxh/qhsan, ‘were defeated at sea.’ With this force of kata/ in composition compare that of de in the Latin debellare. The reference is to the victory won by the Athenian and Persian fleets at Cnidus in August 394 B.C. under the leadership of Conon and Pharnabazus, whereby they destroyed the maritime power of Sparta.

h( de\ po/lis h(mw=n kte( On the return of Conon to Athens the Long
Walls were rebuilt and the Peiraeus refortified. In 395 B.C. Athens had taken the decisive step of forming an alliance with Thebes; after Cnidus some of her former allies, who had belonged to the Delian confederacy, again joined her, and Delos itself was recovered. It seemed for the moment to the Athenians that their former maritime supremacy was to be renewed.

tou=to parasxo/ntos: see critical note. The phrase must mean lit. ‘Evagoras having provided this’, so, ‘it was Evagoras who rendered it possible’ (F.). au(to
 parasxo/ntos would mean ‘having lent his personal service’, but au(to
 pare/xein is generally used with an adjective in agreement; cp. ad N. 20 a)
 w(s be/ltiston kai\ dikaio/taton sauto
 pare/xh|s, ‘if you show yourself as good and just as possible.’

Athens showed her appreciation of Evagoras by setting up his statue. His achievements frightened the King of Persia much more than Cyrus had done. During the Cyprian war he spent 15,000 talents in ten years in trying to subdue him. Evagoras actually increased his territory and invaded Phoenicia, so that at last the Great King was only too glad to make peace, having never been able to capture Salamis with a vast armament, though Evagoras had seized it with only fifty men.

ou(=per kte(: namely in the Ceramicus near the stoa\ basi/leios or Royal Portico; cp. Paus. i. 3. 2, ‘Near the Portico stand Conon and Timotheus, son of Conon, and Evagoras, King of the Cyprians, who carried out the negotiations by which the Phoenician triremes were lent to Conon by King Artaxerxes. Evagoras acted as an Athenian citizen, for his family came originally from Salamis, and he traced his descent from Teucer and the daughter of Kinyras. Here too stands Zeus, called Eleutherios.’ The Ceramicus, ‘Potters' Quarter,’ was situated partly inside the walls of Athens, and partly outside them, near the Dipylon Gate. The stoa\ basi/leios was inside the walls between this gate and the so-called ‘Theseum’; its exact site is uncertain. (See Harrison and Verrall, Mythology and Monuments of Ancient Athens, pp. 14-24.) An account of the distinction conferred on Conon is given by Demosthenes (in Lept. 68-74), from which we learn (§ 70) that the statue of Conon was of bronze; doubtless that of Evagoras was of the same material.
sfw=n au)tw=n: see note on § 53 sfa=s au)tou/s.
kathrga/santo: another form of kateirga/santo, found also in inscriptions (see Meisterhans-Schwyzer, Gram. der Attischen Inschriften^{3}, p. 171).

peri\ me\n ou)=n *ko/nwnos a)/llos h(mi=n e)/stai lo/gos: these words seem to imply that Isocrates intended to write an encomium upon Conon, a project which he does not appear to have carried out. Such a work may have been suggested by his close friendship with Conon's son, Timotheus (Antidos. 101).
o(/ti de\ . . . laqei=n: lit. ‘he did not seek to escape notice, that such was his feeling towards Evagoras’, we should say, ‘he did not try to conceal that,’ &c. For lanqa/nein see note on § 42.
to\n e)n *ku/prw| po/lemon: for the Cyprian war see Introduction, p. 20.

*ku=ron to\n peri\ th=s basilei/as a)mfisbhth/santa: the reference is to the famous expedition of Cyrus, described by Xenophon (Anab. i), when he attempted to win the kingdom of Persia from his brother Artaxerxes II, and perished at the battle of Cunaxa (401 B.C.).
me/giston de\ tekmh/rion: tou= ga/r: see note on § 8 shmei=on de\ me/giston.
tou= me/n: i. e. Cyrus.

mikrou= dei=n, ‘almost.’ For the genitive see note on tosou/tou de/w, § 21. The infinitive is an absolute infinitive, used parenthetically with or without w(s (cp. w(s e)moi\ dokei=n or e)moi\ dokei=n); mikrou= dei=n is lit. ‘to want but little’, so ‘almost’. By an ellipse we also get mikrou= and o)li/gou (dei=n being omitted); cp. Plato, Rep. 552 D o)li/gou pa/ntes, ‘almost all.’

mikrou= dei=n e)/laqen kte(, ‘he almost appeared before his palace before he was aware of him,’ lit. ‘almost escaped notice appearing’, &c. According to Xenophon the battle was fought 360 stades (about 45 miles) from Babylon.

e)pi\ to\ basi/leion e)pista/s: for this use of the intrans. tenses of e)fi/sthmi cp. de Pace 41 e)cai/fnhs e)pista\s toi=s gignome/nois, ‘suddenly appearing on the scene of action’; it is also used of appearances in dreams (Helen. 65).
pro\s de\ tou=ton: i.e. Evagoras.
e)k pollou=: we should say, ‘for a long time.’

metacu\ pa/sxwn eu)=, ‘at a time when he was receiving kindness at
his hands.’ metacu/ is used with a participle when the action of the principal verb occurs at a point of time during the action described by the participle; similarly a(/ma with the participle implies contemporaneous action of the participle and principal verb. The position of eu)= is due to a desire to avoid hiatus; cp. N. C. 7 tou= fronei=n eu)=.

e)k tapeinw=n kai\ fau/lwn pragma/twn, ‘starting from humble and lowly circumstances.’ For this use of e)k cp. § 66 e)c i)diw/tou tu/rannon . . . e)k barba/rwn *(/ellhnas, and Soph. O. T. 454 tuflo\s e)k dedorko/tos.
e)pido/seis: see note on § 7.

ou) kata\ mikro\n gignome/nas: either (1) ‘were anything but gradual’, lit. ‘were not taking place little by little’, in which case kata/ is used distributively (cp. kaq' e(/na, ‘one by one’); or (2) ‘were not inconsiderable’, kata/ being used in the sense of ‘according to’ and kata\ mikro/n meaning ‘on a small scale’. The former seems to make the best sense here. In N. C. 10 kata\ mikro/n is used in the latter sense, and may be translated ‘to a small extent’.
ou)x u(pe\r tw=n gegenhme/nwn o)rgizo/menos: the reference is to the hostilities in Cyprus itself, where Soli and Citium had appealed to Persia against Evagoras.
polu\ peri\ meizo/nwn: this order of words is more emphatic than the more usual peri\ polu\ meizo/nwn.
w(/rmhsen, ‘threw himself into the war.’ o(rma=n can be used in the active either (1) transitively ‘to set in motion’, or (2), as here, intransitively ‘to set oneself in motion’.
ta/lanta pentakisxi/lia: about £1,200,000.
pa/sais a)poleleimme/nos tai=s duna/mesin: see note on § 18 ou)deno\s de\ tw=n o)nomastw=n a)poleifqe/ntos.
h)\ toi=s a)/llois: i.e. h)\ e)n toi=s a)/llois.
*pnutago/ran: when Evagoras was defeated at sea in 386 B. C., his younger son Pnytagoras held Salamis while his father went to Egypt to get help.
mikrou= me\n e)de/hse: personal construction, see note on § 21 tosou/tou de/w.

*ku/pron a(/pasan: we have evidence of the extension of Evagoras' rule in Cyprus in the fact that he probably issued a silver coinage at Amathus in the south of Cyprus about 391 B.C. (see Brit. Mus. Cat. of Coins of Cyprus, p. 3).

*foini/khn d' e)po/rqhse kte(: cp. Paneg. 161, ‘Have not Egypt and Cyprus revolted from him (the King of Persia), Phoenicia and Syria been desolated by the war, and Tyre, on which he greatly prided himself, been seized by his enemies (i.e. Evagoras and the Cyprians)? And of the cities of Cilicia the majority are held by our supporters.’
teleutw=n, ‘finally’; an idiomatic use of the participle in an adverbial sense; cp. o(/per a)rxo/menos ei)=pon (ad N. 54), ‘as I said at first.’
e)ne/plhsen au)tou\s tou= polemei=n, ‘gave them their fill of fighting.’
to\n a)/llon xro/non: see note on § 27.

th\n ei)rh/nhn e)poih/santo: according to Diodor. (15. 9), Evagoras was to be King of Salamis and to pay a fixed tribute, and to be subject to the King of Persia, ‘as a king obeying the commands of a king’ (w(s basileu\s basilei= prosta/ttonti).
kinh/santes: see note on kinei=n, § 7.

a)fei/leto: the subject is the King of Persia. It is a gross exaggeration on the part of Isocrates to represent the sea victory won by Conon and the allied Athenian and Persian fleets at Cnidus as having overthrown the power of Sparta. It put an end to their supremacy at sea, but their land empire lasted until the battle of Leuctra (371 B.C.).
o(\ de\ pa/ntwn deino/taton: th\n ga/r: see note on shmei=on de\ me/giston, § 8.

Evagoras deserves even higher praise than the heroes who besieged Troy; they aided by all Greece captured one city in Asia, while Evagoras with only one city made war on all Asia. He restored his family on the throne and rescued Cyprus from barbarism, and his achievements in the Cyprian war will never be forgotten, while by his assistance Greece was delivered from the bondage of Sparta. It is difficult to decide which of his deeds deserves the highest praise.
u(perbalo/menos: see note on u(perbolh/n, § 1.
u(mnou/menon: see note on u(mnoume/nous, § 6.
tosou=toi to\ plh=qos: see note on to\ me/geqos, § 19.
polu\ a)/n: for the hiatus cp. § 51.

ti/na ga\r eu(rh/somen . . . ei) . . . skopoi=men: a slightly irregular but
perfectly natural condition, ‘whom shall we find, if we were to look?’ Cp. ad N. 45 ei) q)e/loimen . . . eu(rh/somen.
e)c i)diw/tou tu/rannon . . . e)k barba/rwn *(/ellhnas: see note on e)k tapeinw=n kai\ fau/lwn pragma/twn, § 59.
to\ de\ ge/nos, ‘his family.’
politei/as: see note on § 46.

a)/meikton: this form rather than a)/mikton is found in the best MS. (cp. Sophist. 16 mei=cai). A similar spelling is found in the papyrus of the Hellenica Oxyrhynchia, xiv. I summei=cai, and in inscriptions, see Meisterhans-Schwyzer, Gram. der Attischen Inschriften^{3}, p. 181. a)/meiktos means either (1) ‘not mixing’, so ‘unsociable’, ‘having no intercourse with strangers’, as here (= tou\s *(/ellhnas ou) prosdexo/menon, § 47) and of the Cyclops (Eur. Cycl. 428), or (2) passively, ‘unmixed’, ‘pure’.
o(mologoume/nws: see note on peplanwme/nws, § 43.

a(pa/shs th=s *)asi/as ku/rios kate/sth. Clarke is probably right in referring this to the immediate result of the battle of Cnidus rather than to the Peace of Antalcidas (387 B. C.), as Schneider takes it.
h)/peiron: see note on § 55.
e)pe/dosan: see note on e)pido/seis, § 7.
tou\s pro/teron au)tw=n a)/rxontas kte(: Isocr. (Areop. 65) tells us that after the battle of Cnidus ‘ambassadors came from the Lacedaemonians offering to hand over to Athens the command of the sea’.
po/teron: strictly speaking means ‘which of two alternatives’ (Latin utrum) but is here, as often, followed by several alternatives introduced by h)\ . . . h)\ . . .
kaq' o(/ ti a)/n: Isocrates regularly admits a hiatus in this phrase; cp. ad N. § 28 and 35.

kaq' o(/ ti a)
 e)pisth/sw th
 gnw/mhn: Ist aor. subj. in an indefinite clause, ‘to which ever I turn my attention’; e)fista/nai is more often used by itself in this meaning; cp. the omission of to
 nou=n in the phrase prose/xein (to
 nou=n).

p.title: If any one ever deserved immortality, Evagoras is worthy of it. Most heroes have suffered some calamity, but Evagoras was uniformly successful and happy. He was well born; he lived to a ripe old age; he was blessed with numerous children, who were worthy
p.hi: of such a father. If any one was ever a god among men, Evagoras deserves such a title.

div2.p: e)nqa/de, ‘here on earth,’ as in § 2.
tw=n h(miqe/wn: Isocr. is probably thinking of Heracles, the hero par excellence of Greek mythology.

ti/ ga\r a)pe/lipen eu)daimoni/as, ‘in what respect did he lack happiness?’ Evagoras is the subject, ti/ is an adverbial acc., and eu)daimoni/as a partitive gen. For the various uses of a)polei/pein see note on § 18.
toiou/twn progo/nwn: cp. § 13-18.

plh
 ei)/ tis a)po\ tw=n au)tw=n e)kei/nw| ge/gonen, ‘unless he were a member of the same family.’ e)kei/nw| dat. after tw=n au)tw=n; cp. th
 au)th
 gnw/mhn toi=s . . . peripi/ptousi, § 27.
dih/negken: see note on § 14.
peri\ au(tou=: for the hiatus see note on § 3.
tosou=ton d' e)bi/w xro/non: on the death of Evagoras see Introd. p. 20.
h(liki/an: see note on tw=n h(likiwtw=n, § 22.

eu)paidi/as: ‘the possession of a goodly offspring’ was regarded by the Greeks as one of the greatest blessings which the gods could bestow on mortals; cp. Busiris 41 th=s me\n h(mete/ras eu)paidi/as ei)s tou\s qeou\s th\n ai)ti/an a)nafe/romen, and Aristoph. Wasps 1512 w)= maka/rie th=s eu)paidi/as.

ou)de/n: the masc. ou)de/na (see critical note) would be more natural, but this use of the neuter for masculine is not uncommon in Greek. Firstly, the neuter singular is used collectively, e.g. to\ a)/llo *(ellhniko/n (= oi( a)/lloi *(/ellhnes) (Thuc. iv. 20), to\ a)nqrw/peion (= oi( a)/nqrwpoi) (ib. 61); secondly, the neuter plural is often used as equivalent to a masculine plural, e.g. ta)/lla (= tou\s a)/llous) (Aristoph. Ranae 809, Lysistr. 860), a)gaqou\s a)ndriantopoiou\s kai\ ta)/lla ta\ toiau=ta (= tou\s a)/llous tou\s toiou/tous) (Xen. Oec. vi. 13). Here tw=n e)c au)tou= gegono/twn ou)de/n is perhaps rather more emphatic than ou)de/na would have been, as we might say in colloquial English, ‘nothing in the way of children’; cp. the common use of ou)de/n and mhde/n of persons, e.g. ou)de/n ei)mi (Soph. Phil. 951), to\ mhde\n o)/ntas (Ajax 1275). See also note on N. C. 33 a)mfo/tera tau=ta.

a)lla\ to
 me
 basile/a kte(: Schneider compares Harpocration p. 18. 4 oi( me
 ui(oi\ tou= basile/ws kai\ oi( a)delfoi\ kalou=ntai a)/naktes (princes),
ai( de\ a)delfai\ kai\ gunai=kes a)/nassai (princesses). *)aristote/lhs e)n th=| *kupri/wn politei/a|.
u(perbolai=s: here ‘exaggeration’; cp. the English rhetorical figure of speech hyperbole; see note on u(perbolh/n, § 1.
fu/sin: see note on § 49.

I have omitted much that might be said in praise of Evagoras; my age must be my excuse. I have attempted to give a picture of his acts and thoughts—a more useful memorial than a portrait or statue, for (1) great men pride themselves on great deeds, not on their physical appearance; (2) statues must remain where they are set up, but the fame of great deeds can travel far and wide; (3) no one would model himself on a statue, but men can imitate the lives of others as set forth in a written discourse.
tw=n me\n ou)=n ei)s *eu)ago/ran polla/, ‘much that relates to Evagoras.’

u(steri/zw th=s a)kmh=s th=s e)mautou=, ‘I am past my prime of life’; cp. N. C. 19 u(steri/zousi tw=n pragma/twn, ‘they let the moment for action go by,’ lit. ‘are too late for action’. The genitive is due to the idea of comparison contained in the verb. On the date of the Evagoras see Introd. p. 20.
ou) mh\n a)lla/: see note on § 33.

o(/son kata\ th
 e)mh
 du/namin: sc. e)sti/. Schneider compares Isaeus 7. 41 kai\ mh
 kai\ e)me/ ge, o(/sa kata\ th
 e)mh
 h(liki/an, eu)rh/sete ou) kako/n.
*nikoklei=s: see Introd. p. 21.

ta\s tw=n swma/twn ei)ko/nas: cp. ad N. 36 bou/lou ta\s ei)ko/nas th=s a)reth=s u(po/mnhma ma=llon h)\ tou= sw/matos katalipei=n, and Xen. Ages. 11. 7 tou= me\n sw/matos ei)ko/na sth/sasqai a)pe/sxeto, . . . th=s de\ yuxh=s ou)de/pote e)pau/eto mnhmei=a diaponou/menos. Schneider compares Plut. Cimon 2 and Cic. pro Arch. 12.

e)n toi=s lo/gois . . . toi=s texnikw=s e)/xousi, ‘in speeches composed according to the rules of art’; cp. ad N. 44 tw=n ou(/tw texnikw=s pepoihme/nwn. texnikw=s is also used in a bad sense, ‘cunningly,’ ad N. 1 and N. C. 52; cp. te/xnh|, ad N. 28.
prokri/nw de\ tau/tas, ‘I prefer the latter,’ i.e. ei)ko/nas tw=n pra/cewn kai\ th=s dianoi/as.
tou\s kalou\s ka)gaqou/s: see note on § 51.
semnunome/nous e)pi/: see note on semno/taton, § 40. For e)pi/ cp. me/ga fronei=n e)pi/, § 45.
tu/pous, ‘representations,’ including both statues and pictures, as is shown by toi=s . . . peplasme/nois kai\ gegramme/nois (§ 75).
e)cenexqh=nai/ q' oi(=o/n t): q) has been inserted by most editors to avoid the hiatus; its omission was probably due to the oi(=o/n t) immediately following.
diadoqe/ntas, ‘spread abroad.’ dia/ in composition, like the Latin di-, dis-, often has a distributive force; cp. diape/mpein (Latin dimittere).

e)n tai=s tw=n eu)= fronou/ntwn diatribai=s a)gapa=sqai, ‘are welcomed in the discussions of men of good understanding.’ For diatribh/ see note on diatri/bein, § 31. a)gapa=n often merely means ‘to be content with’, as in § 81 and N. C. 12.
pro\s de\ tou/tois o(/ti, ‘further, because,’ introducing a third reason.
tou\s de\ tro/pous tou\s a)llh/lwn, ‘the habits of one another.’ Coraes suggests a)/llwn, which perhaps gives better sense, but there seems no valid reason for altering the reading.
e)n toi=s legome/nois, ‘spoken discourses’ (= e)n toi=s lo/gois toi=s texnikw=s e)/xousi, § 73).
r(a|qumei=n: see note on § 35 r(a/|qumos.

My object in this Speech has been to encourage you, Nicocles, and the other descendants of Evagoras. I do so, not because you are indifferent or unambitious; for every one knows that you are a splendid example of a prince who is also a philosopher. My position is rather that of a spectator who cheers the winner in a race. Prove yourself worthy of your descent from Zeus and your father's virtues; do not be content merely to excel others, rather leave them far behind. This you will do if you continue in your present course.
lo/gon, ‘discourse,’ as in § 4.
qewrei=n: an infin. which carries on the meaning of paradoi/h u(mi=n, ‘were to submit them for your contemplation.’

sundiatri/bein: (see note on § 31 diatri/bein) lit. ‘to spend time with’, so here, ‘study’; cp. Paneg. 158 tw=n mu/qwn h(/dista sundiatri/bomen toi=s *trwi+koi=s. In ad N. 27, 43 it is used literally ‘spend time with’.
tou\s . . . a)/llous: i.e. those who do not belong to the family of Evagoras.
filosofi/an: see Introd. p. 14.
tw=n au)tw=n e)kei/nois: see note on § 27 th\n au)th\n gnw/mhn toi=s peripi/ptousin.
mhdeno\s h(=tton, ‘less than none,’ so ‘better than any’.
dunh/sei: after se\ kai\ tou\s sou/s the plural would be expected, but Isocrates addresses himself particularly to Nicocles.

mh\ no/mize/ me katagignw/skein w(s nu=n a)melei=s, ‘do not imagine that I am accusing you of indifference in your present conduct.’ a)melei=s is here used absolutely as in ad N. 10 mh\ r(a|qumei=n mhd' a)melei=n.
ou)/t' e)me\ le/lhqas ou)/te tou\s a)/llous, o(/ti: see note on lanqa/nein, § 42.
diatribw=n, ‘studies,’ see § 31.

a)feme/nous e)f' oi(=s, ‘abandoning the pursuits in which they now take such great pleasure.’ An antecedent to e)f' oi(=s such as e)kei/nwn must be supplied as object of a)feme/nous, see note on § 26 e)c w(=n d' oi(=o/n t) h)=n.
a)poleleimme/nois: see note on § 18.

e)mo
 me
 ou)=n e)/rgon kai\ tw=n a)/llwn fi/lwn, ‘it is my duty and that of your other friends.’ e)mo/n being a possessive pronoun can be coupled with a genitive; it can also have a genitive depending on it; cp. N. C. 49 tou\s u(mete/rous au)tw=n, and 55 th
 u(mete/ran au)tw=n a)reth/n.
toiau=ta . . . e)c w(=n: for the relative introducing a consecutive clause cp. § 35 ou(/tw r(a/|qumos, o(/stis.

to
 loipo
 xro/non: see note on § 27 to
 a)/llon xro/non.
w(s, ‘for,’ used here as a connecting particle; cp. the use of w(/ste, ‘therefore,’ ad N. 11, 46.
xrh\ d' ou)k a)gapa=n, ei) kte(, ‘you must not be content with being already superior to those around you.’
