toiou=tos . . . th\n fu/sin . . . toiou/tou th\n a)reth/n: cp. § 19 thlikau=ta to\ me/geqos and note.
to\ me\n palaio\n . . . to\ d' u(poguio/taton, ‘distantly . . . immediately,’ adverbial accusatives. u(po/guios, lit. ‘under the hand’, so ‘recent’, ‘fresh’.
e)pi\ soi/, ‘in your power’; cp. Paneg. 142 to\ e)p' e)kei/nw|, ‘as far as in him lay.’
e)pididw=|s: see note on § 7 e)pido/seis.

When private individuals bring presents of gold and raiment to princes, who have already abundance of such things, their gifts are of the nature of commercial transactions. The gift I bring is advice to a monarch; I hope it may be useful.
*niko/kleis: see Introd. p. 21.
e)sqh=tas a)/gein h)\ xalko\n h)\ xruso/n: perhaps a reminiscence of Hom. Od. xvi. 231 xalko/n te xruso/n te a(/lis e)sqh=ta/ q' u(fanth/n.

li/an e)/docan ei)=nai/ moi katafanei=s: li/an qualifies katafanei=s and probably owes its position to a desire to avoid hiatus which would be caused by ploutei=te and e)/docan coming together; cp. E. 48 polu\ li/an a)poleifqw= and note.
texnikw/teron: see note on E. 73.
kaphleu/ein: usually of ‘retail trading’ (often with a further meaning of ‘cheating’), here confined to ‘trading’ in general.

Private individuals have the following advantages over princes: (1) they are schooled by the necessities of daily life, (2) the laws restrain them and their fellow men criticize them, (3) the poets have left them precepts by which to live.
to\ mh\ trufa=n a)ll' a)nagka/zesqai: we should say, ‘the absence of luxury and the necessity,’ &c.
tw=n poihtw=n tines: such as the Gnomic poets Hesiod, Theognis, and Phocylides, whom he mentions in § 42, where see notes.

u(poqh/kas, ‘precepts.’ u(potiqe/nai, lit. ‘place beneath’, ‘put down’, means in the middle voice (1) ‘to lay down as a foundation on principle’, so here u(poqh/kh means ‘a principle’, ‘precept’; (2) ‘to lay down as a presupposition’, ‘to presuppose’, as in § 13 oi(=on u(peqe/meqa dei=n ei)=nai to\n o)rqw=s basileu/sonta, hence u(po/qesis, ‘hypothesis’; (3) ‘to propose as a subject of discussion’, as in N. C. 14 e)nteu=qen u(potiqe/menos h)rca/mhn; cp. u(po/qesis, ‘subject’, ‘design’ (§ 7). In the active it has a technical legal meaning ‘to put down as a pledge’, so ‘mortgage’; cp. French hypothèque.

p.title: Princes are less fortunately placed; their position isolates them, and those who come into contact with them flatter rather than ad-
p.hi: monish them. In fact, they often make such bad use of their opportunities that many people would prefer to live justly in a private station rather than unjustly as princes.

div2.p: toi=s de\ tura/nnois ou)de\n u(pa/rxei toiou=ton, ‘but monarchs have no such advantages,’ lit. ‘but nothing of such a kind belongs to monarchs’. For u(pa/rxein see note on E. 19.
a)nouqe/thtoi: the force of the verbal adjective is ‘in such a position that they cannot be admonished’.
pro\s xa/rin: lit. ‘with a view to favour’, ‘in order to please’.
o(milou=sin, ‘converse with’, ‘associate with’. o(milei=n, lit. ‘to be together with’, so ‘associate with’, ‘converse with’, ‘deal with’ (followed by dat. § 39, pro/s and acc. § 24).
a)formai=s: see note on E. 28.
a)poble/ywsin ei)s: see note on E. 24.

o(pwsou=n zh=n, ‘to live any sort of life,’ i.e. to live in extreme poverty. For o(pwsou=n (Latin quacumque ratione) cp. Philip. 7 o(/pws ga\r ou)=n pepra=xqai (th\n ei)rh/nhn) krei=tton h)=n, ‘it was better to make peace on any terms.’
lusitelei=n: (lu/ein te/los) lit. ‘to pay expenses’, so ‘to be profitable’; cp. the colloquial English ‘it pays to do so and so’.
meta\ toiou/twn sumforw=n: meta/ often connects circumstances with persons; cp. Areop. 52 meta\ tosau/ths a)sfalei/as dih=gon, ‘they lived in such security.’

The office of king, like that of priest, is often held to be easy; really it is the greatest of human responsibilities. I can give no rules for individual actions, only general principles. I hope my achievement will be worthy of my design: it is no mean task, and its success will benefit not only the ruler, but also his countless subjects.

tau/ths de\ th=s a)nwmali/as kai\ th=s taraxh=s, ‘this inconsistency and confusion of ideas,’ i.e. in the minds of those who try to weigh the respective merits of kingship and a private station. For a)nwmali/a see note on a)nwma/lws, E. 44. taraxh/ is often used of ‘mental confusion’; cp. Antidos. 249 o(\ d' ou) mo/non taraxh=s shmei=o/n e)stin a)lla\ kai\ th=s peri\ tou\s qeou\s o)ligwri/as; in N. C. 31, 55 it is used in its literal and more general sense.

th\n basilei/an w(/sper i(erwsu/nhn panto\s a)ndro\s ei)=nai, ‘that the office
of king like that of priest can be performed by any one.’ panto\s a)ndro/s, lit. ‘the part of any man’, an extension of the possessive genitive; cp. Plato, Repub. 335 B e)/stin a)/ra dikai/ou a)ndro\s bla/ptein kai\ o(ntinou=n a)nqrw/pwn; for pa=s ‘every’, so ‘any’, see note on E. 39 e)k panto\s tro/pou.
o(/: here almost introducing a concessive clause ‘though really it is a most important function’.
e)c w(=n: an antecedent must be supplied from e)c w(=n as the object of sumbouleu/ein; cp. note on E. 26 e)c w(=n oi(=o/n t' h)=n.
kata\ tro/pon, ‘aright.’ tro/pos (like Latin modus) often has the meaning of ‘due measure’. The opposite of kata\ tro/pon is a)po\ tro/pou, ‘unduly.’
dioikei=n: here used absolutely, without an object, ‘to govern.’
kaq' o(/lwn tw=n e)pithdeuma/twn, ‘as regards your general line of conduct’ (F.), as opposed to kaq' e(ka/sthn th\n pra=cin, ‘each individual act.’
w(=n . . . dielqei=n: the object of dielqei=n is an antecedent supplied from w(=n.
peri\ a(/: for the hiatus see note on E. 3.
u(poqe/sews: see note on § 3 u(poqh/kas.
tw=n meta\ me/trou poihma/twn: meta\ me/trou is unnecessary, but is inserted to balance kataloga/dhn. For me/tron see note on E. 10.
kataloga/dhn: lit. ‘in the manner of conversation’, so ‘in prose’.
pare/sxen . . . e)/laben: gnomic aorists; cp. E. 4 kate/sthsan.
polu\ katadeeste/ran kte(, ‘have won a reputation which falls far short of expectation.’
ou) mh\n a)lla/: see note on E. 33.
ta\ paraleleimme/na: sc. u(po\ tw=n a)/llwn, ‘a subject which has been neglected.’

nomoqetei=n tai=s monarxi/ais, ‘to legislate for the kingly office.’ Some editors have supposed these words to be corrupt on account of the dative tai=s monarxi/ais, and on the ground that Isocrates does not pose as a ‘lawgiver’ (nomoqe/ths). The MS. reading, however, is perfectly intelligible: nomoqetei=n is here used absolutely ‘to act as lawgiver’, and tai=s monarxi/ais (abstract for the concrete toi=s mona/rxois) is dative of advantage. The whole phrase is almost an example of oxymoron, since the mo/narxos would naturally dispense with laws. nomoqetei=n is also used absolutely in N. C. 7 followed by peri/.
politei/as: see note on E. 46.

We must first grasp the meaning of kingship. The duty of a king is to save his state from misfortune, to preserve its prosperity, and to raise it to greatness. Such a task requires more than usual wisdom; no athlete needs to train his body as carefully as a king should train his mind, and the prizes to be won by kings are proportionately greater.
a)\n ga\r . . . perila/bwmen, ‘for if we properly grasp the scope of the subject as a whole in its main outlines’ (F.).
e)ntau=q' a)poble/pontes, ‘if we keep our attention fixed upon that’ (i.e. th\n du/namin o(/lou tou= pra/gmatos). e)ntau=qa = ei)s tau/thn.

mega/lhn e)k mikra=s: for this use of e)k cp. E. 59 e)k tapeinw=n and note. Themistocles (Plut. Them. 2. 3) is said to have boasted o(/ti lu/ran me
 a(rmo/sasqai kai\ metaxeiri/sasqai ou)k e)pi/staito, po/lin de\ mikra
 kai\ a)/docon paralabw
 e)/ndocon kai\ mega/lhn a)perga/sasqai.
tou\s tau=ta dunhsome/nous, ‘those who are to be able to do these things.’
thlikou/twn: see note on E. 19.
r(a|qumei=n: see note on r(a/|qumos, E. 35.
a)melei=n: used absolutely; cp. E. 78 and note.

de/deiktai ga\r kte(: for the sentiment cp. E. 41 h(gou/menos me/n, ei) kalw=s th\n au(tou= fro/nhsin paraskeua/seie, kalw=s au(tw=| kai\ th\n basilei/an e(/cein. de/deiktai might have indicated a direct reference to this passage in the Evagoras, but for the fact that this speech is certainly the earlier of the two (see Introd. pp. 20, 21). de/deiktai is therefore in the sense of ‘it is well known’ (Latin constat), lit. ‘it has been made clear’, as elsewhere in Isocr., e.g. § 49, Panegyr. 165, cp. Archid. 4 (h)=n dedeigme/non).
w(/st): here a connecting particle, as in § 46; cp. the similar use of w(s, E. 80 and note.
tw=n a)skhtw=n, ‘athletes.’ a)skhth/s, ‘one who practises some trade,’ is used especially of athletes, as in Plat. Rep. 403 E; cp. Hesychius, a)skhth/s, a)qlhth/s and e)paskhtai/, a)qlhtai/.

ou)d' e(\n me/ros tiqe/asi kte(, ‘do not offer a fraction of the prizes for which you kings strive daily.’ For this use of me/ros cp. ta\ du/o me/rh, ‘two-thirds,’ ta\ pe/nte me/rh, ‘five-sixths.’ tiqe/nai is regularly used of ‘offering’ prizes; cp. Hom. Il. xxiii. 262 i(ppeu=sin me\n prw=ta podw/kesin a)gla/) a)/eqla | qh=ke.
peri\ w(=n: for the hiatus see note on E. 3.

Kings must practise diligence as much as other men. Intelligence is as useful in training men as it is in training animals. Associate with the wisest, and never neglect a chance of acquiring wisdom. Remember that it is absurd that a man should rule over those who are wiser and better than himself.

mhde\ katagnw=|s tw=n a)nqrw/pwn tosau/thn dustuxi/an, ‘and do not condemn mankind to such an unfortunate position’ &c. Schneider, on Areop. 49, quotes this passage in support of his view that dustuxei=s there means ‘poor creatures’ (armselige Narren), and renders dustuxi/an in this passage by stoliditatem; there is, however, no reason to suppose that it is not here used in its literal sense.
peri\ ta\ qhri/a te/xnas eu(rh/kamen kte(: Isocr. works out this comparison at great length in Antidos. 211 ff.
ta\s yuxa/s: see note on E. 23.
w(s . . . ou(/tw dia/keiso th\n gnw/mhn: cp. E. 29 ou(/tw die/keito th\n gnw/mhn, w(/sper . . .
tw=n a)/llwn: i.e. wise men of other nations.
metape/mpou: for meta/ in composition see note on E. 50 metapeptw/kasin.
sofistw=n, ‘wise men.’ For the meaning of this word in Isocr. see Introd. p. 14.
a)pei/rws e)/xein: for e)/xein with adverbs see note on E. 30 w(/sper ei)=xen.
e)latto/nwn . . . meizo/nwn, ‘inferiors . . . superiors.’
a)gwnisth/n: (see critical note) equivalent to a)ntagwnisth/n, which some MSS. read.
u(peqe/meqa: see note on § 3 u(poqh/kas.
e)rrwmeneste/rws: for comparative adverbs in -ws see note on E. 5 filotimote/rws, and for adverbs formed from participles see note on E. 43 peplanhme/nws.

au(tou=: for sautou=. The reflexive pronoun of the 3rd person is not infrequently used in Attic Greek in place of that of the 1st and 2nd persons; cp. § 24 pro\s e(auto/n (= seauto/n), § 38 toi=s au(tou= (= seautou=) paisi/n, and Phil. 129 pro\s th
 patri/da th
 au(tou= (= e)mautou=). The use may perhaps be explained by the fact that the 3rd personal reflexive can be used of an indefinite person, so here th
 au(tou= dia/noian might be translated ‘one's own understanding’.

Men, like animals, must be loved before they can be properly trained; therefore you must be a lover of mankind and of your state. Those forms of government last longest where there is affection between the ruler and the ruled.
mele/tw soi tou= plh/qous: Evagoras is praised (E. 46) as dhmotiko\s w)\n th=| tou= plh/qous qerapei/a|.

kexarisme/nws au)toi=s a)/rxein, ‘to rule in a manner which is acceptable to them.’ au)toi=s is to be taken closely with kexaris me/nws. For the adverbs formed from participles cp. e)rrwmeneste/rws (§ 14) and see note on E. 43 peplanhme/nws. For the sentiment cp. Corn. Nep. x. 5 nullum imperium tutum nisi benevolentia munitum, and Claudian, de iv cons. Hon. v. 281 non sic excubiae non circumstantia pila | quam tutatur amor.
kalw=s dhmagwgh/seis, ‘you will make a good popular leader’; cp. dhmotiko/s, E. 46.
a)dikh/sontai: fut. mid. in form and pass. in meaning; cp. E. 5 eu)logh/sontai and note.
tau=ta ga\r stoixei=a kte(, ‘for these are the first and most important elements of good government.’

Do not hesitate to alter existing laws if you can improve upon them. Laws should be consistent and immediate in their action. Make lawsuits costly and industries profitable. Your judgements should be given with care, for they will pass into law. Manage your state as you would your private property; be munificent yet economical, show your magnificence not in extravagant display but in purchasing possessions which are beautiful and lasting.
prostagma/twn, ‘institutions,’ which have the sanction of law.
e)pithdeuma/twn, ‘customs,’ which are sanctioned by public opinion.
ki/nei kai\ metati/qei ta\ mh\ kalw=s kaqestw=ta, ‘change and alter such as are not ordered aright’; cp. E. 7 a)ei/ ti kinei=n tw=n mh\ kalw=s e)xo/ntwn and note.
eu(reth/s: see note on E. 40.
ei) de\ mh/: sc. au)to\s eu(ri/skein dunh/sei.
sfi/sin au)toi=s o(mologoume/nous: see note on ta\s e)n toi=s lo/gois o(mologi/as, E. 44. For the use of the reflexive for the reciprocal pronoun cp. sfa=s au)tou/s, E. 53 and note.
a)mfisbhth/seis, ‘controversies’; cp. Antiphon 131. 7 a)mfisbh/thsin u(polei/pein, ‘to leave room for dispute.’
dialu/seis, ‘settlement.’
prosei=nai: see note on w(=n prosei=nai dei=, E. 46.
e)rgasi/as, ‘industries,’ a general term covering agriculture, commerce, and handicraft.

pragmatei/as: lit. ‘business’, so here in particular of ‘lawsuits’, the chief business of an Athenian in the fourth century B.C. Isocr. when he uses the word in this sense generally qualifies it, e.g. Antidos. 31 th=s peri\ ta\ dikasth/ria pragmatei/as and ib. 40 tw=n pragmateiw=n tw=n peri\ ta\ sumbo/laia gignome/nwn; he probably does not so qualify it here to avoid spoiling the balance of the sentence, in which ta\s de\ pragmatei/as corresponds to ta\s me\n e)rgasi/as.
peri\ w(=n: see note on E. 3.
a)kinh/tws e)/xein peri\ tw=n dikai/wn, ‘should be immutable on questions of justice’ (F.).

oi)/kei: for the more usual dioi/kei cp. Areop. 78 h)
 me
 ou(/tws oi)kw=men th
 po/lin w(/sper nu=n. Isocr. probably uses oi)kei=n here to emphasize his comparison between po/lin and oi)=kon; it is almost an example of o(mwnumi/a see note on E. 36 poihsa/menos . . . pepoi/hntai.
tai=s me\n kataskeuai=s kte(, ‘displaying a royal magnificence in the equipment of your state.’ For kataskeuh/ see note on E. 44.

tai=s de\ pra/cesin a)kribw=s, ‘observing scrupulous accuracy in money matters.’ pra/cesin, ‘transaction of business,’ so ‘money matters’. a)kribw=s is here used in a good sense and is almost equivalent to ‘economically’, it is sometimes used of money matters in a bad sense, ‘stingily,’ as in Andoc. 23. 19 a)kribw=s diaita=sqai.
diarkh=|s: here used absolutely, ‘keep within your means’ (F.).
mhd' e)n mia=|: see note on E. 43 ou)de\ peri\ e(/n.
e)/n te toi=s proeirhme/nois: i.e. e)n tai=s lamprai=s kai\ basilikai=s kataskeuai=s.

tw=| ka/llei tw=n kthma/twn: it was a characteristic principle among the Greeks that everything around them, even the most ordinary articles of everyday use, should be as beautiful as possible; cp. E. 50 xai/rein de\ kai\ toi=s kth/masi kai\ toi=s e)pithdeu/masi toi=s *(ellhnikoi=s, and note.
tai=s tw=n fi/lwn eu)ergesi/ais, ‘acts of generosity towards your friends.’ tw=n fi/lwn is an objective genitive.
In religious matters follow the traditions of your forefathers, and remember that the highest service which you can render to the gods is to live justly.

ta\ pro\s tou\s qeou/s, ‘in matters of religion,’ probably an accusative standing in relation to the whole sentence and not the object of poi/ei; cp. for somewhat similar accusatives N. C. 2 ta\ peri\ tou\s qeou\s eu)sebou=men and note, and Thuc. vii. 31 au)toi\ de\ ta\ peri\ th=s stratia=s to\n cu/llogon h(toima/zonto.
kate/deican: katadeiknu/nai is regularly used of those who initiate something new; cp. Paneg. 47 filosofi/an h( po/lis h(mw=n kate/deice.
qerapei/an: see note on E. 28 qerapeu/ein.
kataba/llontas, ‘sacrifice’; cp. Hesych. kataba/llontes: ktei/nontes, sfa/zontes, and Eur. Bacch. 1246 kalo\n to\ qu=ma katabalou=sa dai/mosin.
pra/cein ti . . . a)gaqo/n, ‘win a blessing’; cp. Hesych. pra/ssein: labei=n.

ti/ma . . . eu)nousta/tous: for reading see critical note. The passage is probably corrupt. As it stands it must be translated, ‘honour the most intimate of your friends by the bestowal of public appointments, but in actual reality honour those who are best disposed towards you.’ The contrast between tou\s oi)keiota/tous and tou\s eu)nousta/tous does not give very satisfactory sense; and in any case the precept does not belong here, but rather to § 27, where the question of appointment to offices is discussed. The phrase tai=s a)lhqei/ais au)tai=s is quite Isocratean, and is merely a stronger form of tai=s a)lhqei/ais, which is found in Antid. 283 tau=ta kai\ tai=s a)lhqei/ais ou(/tws e)/xei, ‘these things are so in very truth’ (cp. Philemon fr. 40 tai=s a)lhqei/aisin). The readings of the inferior MSS. are doubtless attempts made by copyists to improve the passage. Lange suggests a)rgai=s for a)rxai=s; this, taken with tw=n timw=n, the reading of *l and the Marseilles papyrus, would make good sense if translated ‘with unremunerative offices’; but Isocrates can hardly have written ti/ma . . . tw=n timw=n.

p.title: Your surest protection is the good will of your subjects and your own wisdom. Interest yourself in the homes of your citizens; their resources are yours, if you rule well. Show that your city is well disposed towards strangers, and that it abides by its contracts.
Value rather those who desire favours at your hands than those who wish to bestow favours on you.

div2.p:
fulakh
 a)sfalesta/thn kte(: for the sentiment cp. Helene 37 where Isocr. says of Theseus ou)d' e)peisa/ktw| duna/mei th
 a)rxh
 diafula/ttwn, a)lla\ th=| tw=n politw=n eu)noi/a| doruforou/menos, and Sallust, Iug. 10 non exercitus neque thesauri praesidia regni sunt, uerum amici, and Tac. Hist. iv. 7 nullum maius boni imperii instrumentum quam bonos amicos esse.

tw=n politikw=n: see note on E. 10. Isocr. insists elsewhere on the close relation between the prosperity of the individual and that of the state; cp. N. C. 55 dia\ ta\s taraxa\s a)nagkai=o/n e)sti kai\ ta\s po/leis a)po/llusqai kai\ tou\s oi)/kous tou\s i)di/ous a)nasta/tous gi/gnesqai, and Paneg. 103 e)pi\ toi/nun th=s h(mete/ras h(gemoni/as eu(rh/somen kai\ tou\s oi)/kous tou\s i)di/ous pro\s eu)daimoni/an plei=ston e)pido/ntas.
dapanw=ntas: dapanwme/nous is read by some MSS. Isocr. uses the active and middle of this verb indifferently. It is here used absolutely, ‘those who squander their money.’
a)po\ tw=n sw=n: with a)nali/skein.

tou\s e)rgazome/nous: being directly contrasted with tou\s dapanw=ntas, must here mean ‘those who are trading with their money’ (rather than ‘those who are industrious’ (F.)). For this meaning of e)rga/zesqai cp. Demosth. 893. 24 tou/tois peirw=mai nautikoi=s e)rga/zesqai, ‘I am trying to trade with this money on bottomry.’ e)rga/zesqai is coupled with fei/desqai in Areop. 24.

a(/panta ga\r ta\ tw=n oi)kou/ntwn th\n po/lin oi)kei=a kte(, ‘for all the possessions of those who inhabit the city are the private property of those who rule well’; contrast this ordinary use of oi)kei=n with that of oi)/kei, § 19, where see note on the o(mwnumi/a or play upon words (oi)/kei . . . oi)=kon, oi)kou/ntwn . . . oi)kei=a).
protimw=n, ‘that you value.’ protima=n generally means to ‘prefer’, followed by a genitive of the thing compared.
w(/ste pistote/rous ei)=nai tou\s sou\s lo/gous kte(: cp. Paneg. 81, where Isocrates describes the ancient Athenians as pistote/rois toi=s lo/gois h)\ nu=n toi=s o(/rkois xrw/menoi.
ta\ sumbo/laia, ‘contracts.’ sumbo/laion is lit. a ‘token’, so ‘signature’, esp. of a ‘bond’ or ‘covenant’.
no/mimon: here used in the rare sense of ‘law-abiding’; cp. Antiph˙ Tetral. A. b, 12 (p. 117) filoqu/thn de\ kai\ no/mimon o)/nta.
peri\ plei/stou de\ poiou= kte(: for the sentiment cp. the praise bestowed on the ancient Romans by Sallust (Cat. 6), because magis dandis quam accipiendis beneficiis amicitias parabant.

Relieve your subjects of their fears. Do nothing in anger, but pretend anger if necessary. Let nothing escape you, but do not punish crimes as severely as they deserve. Show your authority by asserting the superiority of your intellect, and by showing your subjects that you have their interests at heart more than they themselves have. Be warlike in your preparation, peaceful in committing no unjust aggression. Be contentious only when victory will bring advantage. Respect those who carry out their ends rather than those who aim at the impossible.

tou\s pollou\s fo/bous e)cai/rei tw=n politw=n, ‘free your subjects from most of their fears,’ i.e. there must be a certain feeling of fear in their minds (e.g. fear of punishment) but other fears must be reduced to a minimum. This seems better than ‘the many fears to which they are liable’ (F.).
poi/ei me\n mhde\n met' o)rgh=s: cp. Cic. de Off. i. 38 cum ira nihil recte fieri, nihil considerate potest.
do/kei de/: sc. o)rgi/zesqai.
o(/tan soi kairo\s h)=|, ‘when occasion arises.’ For the meaning of kairo/s see note on E. 31.
a)rxiko\s ei)=nai bou/lou, ‘desire to show your authority.’ For adjectives in -iko/s see note on dhmotiko/s kte(., E. 46.
mh\ xalepo/thti: for the sentiment cp. E. 45 fobero\s w)\n ou) tw=| polloi=s xalepai/nein a)lla\ tw=| polu\ th\n tw=n a)/llwn fu/sin u(perba/llein.
tw=| pa/ntas h(tta=sqai th=s sh=s dianoi/as, ‘by making others feel the superiority of your intellect.’
polemiko\s kte(: cp. de Pace 136 polemikou\s me\n o)/ntas tai=s mele/tais kai\ tai=s paraskeuai=s, ei)rhnikou\s de\ tw=| mhde\n para\ to\ di/kaion pra/ttein.
tw=| mhde\n para\ to\ di/kaion pleonektei=n, ‘in committing no unjust act of aggression.’ For pleonektei=n see note on E. 11.
o(mi/lei: see note on § 4. For the sentiment cp. Paneg. 81 th\n au)th\n a)ciou=ntes gnw/mhn e)/xein pro\s tou\s h(/ttous h(/nper tou\s krei/ttous pro\s sfa=s au)tou/s.
tw=n po/lewn: partitive genitive after ta\s h(/ttous.
w(/sper a)\n ta\s krei/ttous pro\s e(auto\n a)ciw/seias: sc. o(milei=n. For e(auto/n (= seauto/n) see note on § 14.
peri\ w(=n: hiatus, see note on E. 3 peri\ au(tw=n.
me/llei: the best MS. reads me/lloi (see critical note), an optative which does not admit of explanation, and is probably due to assimilation to soi.

fau/lous h(gou= kte(, ‘consider not those men weak who accept a defeat which is to their advantage, but rather those who win a victory to their own hurt.’ For meta/ see note on § 5 meta\ toiou/twn sumforw=n; and for perigi/gnesqai see note on E. 36.

tou\s mei/zw periballome/nous w(=n oi(=oi/ t' ei)si katasxei=n, ‘those who aim at greater things than they can attain.’ w(=n is for e)kei/nwn a(/ by relative attraction, see note on E. 11 h(=s; the genitive is that of the thing compared after mei/zw.

Envy not those who have wide rule, but those who rule aright. Perfect happiness consists in doing one's duty and having moderate desires. Make friends who will help you to rule well, not those who will amuse your leisure. Remember that you will be judged by your friends, and that you are responsible for the acts of your subordinates.

kthsame/nous . . . xrhsame/nous: ‘designed assonance’ (paronomasi/a) is common in Isocr.; cp. § 46 fqonou=si . . . fronou=si, and Paneg. 45 r(w/mhs . . . gnw/mhs. It is sometimes found in the Greek Tragedians, e.g. h)\ xre/os h)\ qeo/s, and in Latin, e.g. Varro, R. R. iii. 2. 13 utrum propter oues an propter aues. paronomasi/a was a favourite figure of the Sophist Gorgias of Leontini, and was sometimes called ‘figura Gorgiana’.
th=s sh=s fu/sews, ‘your character,’ practically equivalent to sou=; see note on E. 49.
sundiatri/yeis: see note on E. 76.

dokimasi/as, ‘scrutiny’, ‘examination’. dokimasi/a and the verb dokima/zein are often used technically of the examination undergone either (1) by young men who were to be placed upon the roll of citizens, or (2) by magistrates, who had been elected, before entering office, as to their character and rights of citizenship.
toi=s xrwme/nois: see note on E. 44.

toiou/tous: might refer either (1) to what has gone before and
mean tou\s a)kribw=s dedokimasme/nous, or (2) to what is coming, w(s au)to\s . . . e(/cwn, and mean ‘such men that you will be willing to assume the responsibility for what they do’. The latter is most probable, and in that case toiou/tous need not be expressed in English.
toi=s pra/gmasi toi=s mh\ dia\ sou= gignome/nois, ‘such matters as you do not attend to personally.’
w(s au)to\s ta\s ai)ti/as e(/cwn kte(: cp. the words spoken by Maecenas to Augustus (Dio Cass. lii. 37. 6) pa/nta ga/r, o(/s' a)\n h)\ kalw=s h)\ kakw=s pra/cwsi, soi\ prosteqh/setai.

Trust critics rather than flatterers. Allow freedom of speech to men of wisdom, and listen to the judgements which men pass upon one another, and so learn their characters. Rule yourself as well as others; mastery over the passions is the most kingly of all qualities. Choose your friends carefully, and let them be men who will help you and whose friendship will raise you in the estimation of others.
o(/ ti a)/n: for the hiatus see note on E. 39, and cp. § 35.
di/dou parrhsi/an kte(: cp. the saying of Hiero (Plut. Apophth. reg. Hieronis 1) mhde/na tw=n parrhsiazome/nwn pro\s au)to\n a)/kairon ei)=nai.
peri\ w(=n . . . peri\ a)llh/lwn . . . peri\ w(=n: see note on E. 3.
dio/ra, ‘distinguish’; dia/ having the same force as dis- in the Latin discernere. In N. C. 16 it seems rather to mean ‘see through’, with the same force as per in the Latin perspicere.
te/xnh|: in a bad sense, ‘artfully,’ see note on texnikw=s, E. 73.
ple/on . . . e(/xwsin: equivalent to pleonektei=n ‘have an advantage over’, see note on E. 11.
a)/koue tou\s lo/gous kte(: cp. Xen. Agesilaus 11. 4 ou)x h(=tton w)/|eto katamanqa/nein tou\s tw=n lego/ntwn tro/pous h)\ peri\ w(=n le/goien.
a)/rxe sautou=: cp. Seneca, Ep. cxiii imperare sibi maximum imperium est.
tou=q' h(gou= kte(: tou=to is the antecedent of the clause a)\n mhdemia=| . . . politw=n.
a)\n mhdemia=| kte(: cp. E. 45 h(gou/menos tw=n h(donw=n a)ll' ou)k a)go/menos u(p) au)tw=n.
diatribai=s: see note on E. 31 diatri/bein.
e)pidw/seis: see note on E. 7 e)pido/seis.

Do not entertain ambitions such as bad men can achieve. The truest honours are private expressions of respect, not public laudations. Give public utterance to your high aspirations. Do not think that citizens must be orderly, but kings may live lawlessly; the state takes its character from the ruler. The prosperity of the subject is the test of good government.
me/ros . . . me/testin: me/ros is pleonastic, as in N. C. 43.
e)n tw=| fanerw=|, ‘publicly.’
au)toi\ par' au(toi=s o)/ntes: sc. oi( poli=tai.
la/nqane me\n . . . spouda/zwn, ‘make a secret of it, if you happen to delight in anything trivial, but make a public display of your earnestness’ &c. For lanqa/nein see note on E. 42.
tw=n fau/lwn: with e)pi/ tw|.

to\ th=s po/lews o(/lhs kte(: cp. N. C. 37 filei= to\ plh=qos e)n tou/tois toi=s e)pithdeu/masi to\n bi/on dia/gein e)n oi(=s a)\n tou\s a)/rxontas tou\s au(tw=n o(rw=si diatri/bontas, and Cic. Ep. Fam. i. 9. 12 quales in republica principes essent, tales reliquos solere esse ciues, and Liv. i. 21 ipsi se homines in regis, uel unici exempli, mores formarent.
o(moiou=tai toi=s a)/rxousi: i.e. tw=| tw=n a)rxo/ntwn h)/qei; see note on E. 34 pro\s e(/kaston au)tw=n.
shmei=on d' e)/stw kte(: cp. Cic. ad Att. viii. 11 moderatori rei publicae beata ciuium uita proposita est, ut opibus firma, copiis locuples, gloria ampla, uirtute honesta sit.

eu)porwte/rous, ‘more prosperous,’ as in Phil. 103 to
 eu)porw/taton tw=n nu=n peri\ th
 h)/peiron. Isocr. when he uses this word in the sense of ‘rich’ usually qualifies it, e.g. eu)porw/teros ta\ peri\ to
 bi/on (de Pace 19); Demosthenes uses it, without qualification, e.g. Olynth. i. 28 tou\s eu)po/rous, ‘the wealthy classes.’

It is better to leave behind you a good name, which no money can buy, than riches which the wicked can gain. Be rich in your attire, but temperate in your habits of life. Keep a watch on every word and action. The ideal of action is to hit upon the right course, but aim at qualities of defect rather than excess.
h( d' a)qa/natos: see note on E. 16.
xrhma/twn: gen. of price.

a)ll' h)/, ‘except.’ This formula is always used after a negative expressed or implied. It is doubtful whether it stands for a)lla\ h)/
or a)/llo h)/, but while the accentuation favours the former, it seems more likely that the literal meaning of the phrase is ‘otherwise than’, in which case a)/llo (used adverbially) h)/ is more probable. The origin of the phrase had probably been forgotten, and it was used without reference to its original meaning.
karte/rei: used absolutely, ‘exercise self restraint,’ as in N. C. 39 karterei=n duna/menon.

e)n toi=s a)/llois e)pithdeu/masin: lit. ‘in all your other habits of life’, which is strictly speaking slightly illogical, since e)sqh=si kai\ toi=s peri\ to\ sw=ma ko/smois cannot be called e)pithdeu/mata. In English we should not translate a)/llois.
th\n au)th\n e)kei/nois gnw/mhn: see note on E. 27.

kra/tiston me\n kte(, ‘the best thing is to hit the exact course which the occasion demands’ (F.). a)kmh/, lit. ‘edge’, so ‘highest point’, ‘zenith’, and of time the ‘right moment’, is here used in a slightly different sense of ‘the right course’.

e)peidh\ de\ duskatamaqh/tws e)/xousin: sc. oi( kairoi/. a)kmh/ would be the more natural subject, but Isocr. prefers a plural verb in order to avoid hiatus. For e)/xein, with an adverb, see note on E. 30 w(/sper ei)=xen.

e)llei/pein ai(rou= kai\ mh\ pleona/zein kte(, ‘choose not to go far enough rather than to go too far; for the mean consists in defect rather than in excess.’ e)llei/pein and pleona/zein are used absolutely, lit. ‘to fall short . . . to go beyond bounds’. It is a characteristically Greek idea that right action consists in an avoidance of the two extremes of excess and defect, and is the ‘golden mean’ between them. The idea is elaborately worked out by Aristotle, cp. Eth. Nic. ii. 5 (= 1106^{a} 28 ff.) to\ d' i)/son me/son ti u(perbolh=s kai\ e)llei/yews. le/gw de\ tou= me\n pra/gmatos me/son to\ i)/son a)pe/xon a)f) e(kate/rou tw=n a)/krwn; one of the examples he gives is courage (a)ndrei/a), which, he says, is the mean between rashness (qrasu/ths) and cowardice (deili/a). The advice here given by Isocr. is exactly that of Cicero, Orat. xxii etsi suus cuique rei modus est, tamen magis offendit nimium quam parum.

p.title: Be at once polite and dignified; this is not easy, for dignity often has the appearance of coldness, while courtesy leads to a sacrifice of dignity. Pursue any subject which you wish to master
p.hi: both by theory and practice; the two react upon one another. Bear the past in mind; it will help you in dealing with the future.

div2.p: a)stei=os: lit. ‘belonging to the town’ (Latin urbanus), so ‘polite’ (cp. English ‘urbane’), as opposed to a)/groikos ‘belonging to the country’, so ‘rude’, ‘boorish’.
semno/s: see note on E. 40.
tapeinou/s, ‘too humble’, ‘abject’. tapeino/s is used generally in a bad sense in Classical Greek; contrast its use as ‘humble’ in a good sense in the New Testament. Humility was not a Greek virtue.

dei= de\ xrh=sqai me\n a)mfote/rais tai=s i)de/ais tau/tais kte(, ‘you must cultivate both these qualities, and avoid the disadvantage which attaches to each.’ i)de/a, lit. ‘appearance’, ‘form’, so ‘kind’, ‘class’. Here i)de/ai means ‘kinds (i.e. of behaviour)’, ‘qualities’; cp. § 48, and N. C. 30, 44 and E. 9, where ei)=dos is used in the same way, pa=si toi=s ei)/desi (sc. ko/smwn). In Plato i)de/a means a ‘class’, ‘species’, under which individual examples are arranged, and in Aristotle the ‘general idea’ or ‘principle’ underlying such a classification.
prosou=san: a favourite word of Isocr. See note on E. 46.
o(/ ti a)/n: for the hiatus cp. § 28 o(/ ti a)\n le/gh|s.
a)kribw=sai, ‘master’, ‘thoroughly understand’.
w(=n: attracted relative for e)kei/nwn (partit. gen. after o(/ ti) a(/.
e)mpeiri/a|, ‘practice,’ as opposed to filosofi/a|, ‘theory.’
me/tiqi, ‘go after’, so ‘pursue’, ‘study’. For meta/ in composition see note on E. 50 metapeptw/kasin.
ta\s o(dou/s, ‘the methods to be pursued.’
xrh=sqai toi=s pra/gmasi, ‘to deal with events as they arise’; cp. N. C. 30 ta\s xrh/seis tw=n pragma/twn.

a)\n ga\r ta\ parelhluqo/ta kte(: cp. Andoc. 23. 39 xrh\ tekmhri/ois xrh=sqai toi=s pro/teron genome/nois peri\ tw=n mello/ntwn e)/sesqai, and Dion. Halicarn. Antiq. x, p. 471 bouleu/ontai/ te a)/rista peri\ tw=n mello/ntwn oi( paradei/gmata poiou/menoi ta\ gegono/ta tw=n e)some/nwn.

p.title: Kings should so strive to live that they may acquire renown, remembering that private individuals are ready even to die to win glory. Let your virtues be a memorial of you rather than statues set up in your honour. Die gloriously rather than live in dishonour.
Do nothing unworthy of your royal office. Your body will perish, but your deeds can win you immortality.

div2.p: ta\s ei)ko/nas kte(: cp. E. 73 ta\s tw=n swma/twn ei)ko/nas kte(. and note.
kalw=s teqna/nai ma=llon h)\ zh=n ai)sxrw=s: a good example of chiasmus.
basilei/as: here, ‘kingship’, ‘kingly office’.
perii/dh|s: see note on periidei=n, E. 30.
th\n sautou= fu/sin a(/pasan, ‘your whole being’ (F.).
dialuqei=san, ‘dissolved,’ i.e. by death. For another meaning of dialu/ein see N. C. 33.

qnhtou= sw/matos e)/tuxes, ‘you possess a mortal body.’ tugxa/nein with the genitive means ‘to hit upon’, so ‘obtain’, and in the aorist ‘have obtained’, so ‘possess’. The sentiment expressed in these and the following words is very common in Isocrates, e.g. Phil. 134 to\ me
 sw=ma qnhto
 a(/pantes e)/xomen, kata\ de\ th
 eu)logi/an kai\ tou\s e)pai/nous . . . a)qanasi/as metalamba/nomen.
th=s yuxh=s: see note on E. 23.
a)qa/naton th\n mnh/mhn: see note on E. 16.

Speaking of good actions will help you to think of them. Imitate those whose reputation you envy. When you give advice to your children, follow it yourself. The wise are not those who dispute about trifles, but those who speak well on important matters; not those who promise happiness, but those who can bear success or failure with equanimity.

mele/ta peri\ kalw=n e)pithdeuma/twn kte(: for the converse of this maxim cp. Aristot. Pol. vii. 17 (= 1336^{a} 5) e)k tou= ga\r eu)xerw=s le/gein o(tiou=n tw=n ai)sxrw=n gi/netai kai\ to\ poiei=n su/neggus.
e)pite/lei. w(=n kte(: hiatus is allowed here, because the new sentence begins a fresh maxim and a pause is necessary before it.
toi=s au(tou= paisi/n: see note on § 14 au(tou=.
peri\ mikrw=n a)kribw=s . . . eu)= peri\ tw=n mega/lwn: a good example of chiasmus.
o(milei=n: see note on § 4.

mh\ diatarattome/nous kte(: cp. Panath. 30 ff. kalw= pepaideume/nous . . . tou\s mh\ diafqeirome/nous u(po\ tw=n eu)pragiw=n mhd' e)cistame/nous au(tw=n mhd) u(perhfa/nous gignome/nous, a)ll) e)mme/nontas th=| ta/cei th=| tw=n eu)= fronou/ntwn.

xrw= toi=s ei)rhme/nois, ‘make use of these precepts which I have
offered you’; cp. Hor. Ep. i. 6. 67 si quid nouisti rectius istis, | candidus imperti; si non, his utere mecum.
Much that I am saying must be familiar to you; but the object of such a discourse as this is to collect scattered maxims and put them in an attractive form.

o(/ti tosou/twn o)/ntwn . . . e)pithdeu/ontes: the words tosou/twn o)/ntwn to\ plh=qos kai\ tw=n a)/llwn (= i)diwtw=n, which some MSS. read) kai\ tw=n a)rxo/ntwn must be taken together as partitive genitives dependent on oi( me\n . . . oi( de/, ‘among the great number both of private individuals and of rulers, some . . . others . . .’ Less good sense is obtained if tosou/twn o)/ntwn to\ plh=qos be made to refer to tw=n legome/nwn, ‘when my precepts are so numerous.’
a)lla\ ga/r: (Latin at enim) has two meanings in Greek (1) introducing an objection, ‘but some one will say,’ or (2) as here, ‘but the truth is that’ (cp. N. C. 4).
tw=n e)pithdeuma/twn: rightly bracketed by Blass; it probably entered the text owing to some confusion caused by e)pithdeu/ontes in the line before.
e)n oi(=s: causal, ‘since in them.’
tw=n diesparme/nwn e)n tai=s tw=n a)/llwn dianoi/ais, ‘the scattered thoughts of others’ (F.).

Men are apt to consider that those writers who give advice are useful, but they prefer to associate with those who share their own weaknesses. People admit that the Gnomic Poets are the best possible counsellors, but they find more pleasure in their own idle conversation than in reading these poets. They adopt the same attitude towards the moralizings of the Tragic poets—and prefer comedy.
tw=n suggramma/twn, ‘in prose,’ more fully tw=n kataloga/dhn suggramma/twn (§ 7).
a)lla\ pepo/nqasin o(/per kte(, ‘for they have the same feeling towards them as towards those who offer advice.’

plhsia/zein de\ bou/lontai . . . a)potre/pousin, ‘but they like to associate with those who have the same faults as themselves rather than with those who seek to turn them from their faults’; cp. ad Dem. 45 tw=n me\n ga\r a)/llwn tou\s plei/stous eu(rh/somen, w(/sper tw=n
siti/wn toi=s h(di/stois ma=llon h)\ toi=s u(gieinota/tois xai/rontas, ou(/tw kai\ tw=n fi/lwn toi=s sunecamarta/nousi plhsia/zontas a)ll' ou) toi=s nouqetou=sin.

*(hsio/dou: Hesiod of Ascra in Boeotia is the earliest Greek poet except Homer whose works have come down to us. He probably lived in the second half of the ninth century B.C. His chief poem was the Works and Days, a didactic poem on agriculture which contains a number of pithy sayings and criticisms of life. He also wrote a Theogony, an account of the origin of the world; the Shield of Heracles, an imitation of the Homeric account of the Shield of Achilles is also, probably wrongly, attributed to him.

*qeo/gnidos: Theognis, who flourished in the middle of the sixth century B.C., was a noble of Megara who put into elegiac verse the orthodox doctrines of the Dorian aristocracy, which he desired to instil into the mind of his young friend Cyrnus. About 1,400 lines have come down to us bearing his name; but the text is much confused by additions made when he was used as a standard author in the schools of Athens, where the respectability of his views made his poem a favourite textbook.

*fwkuli/dou: Phocylides of Miletus, who also flourished in the middle of the sixth century B.C., was another elegiac moralist, of whom very few fragments have survived, mainly in the form of elegiac couplets introduced by the words kai\ to/de *fwkuli/dou. A hexameter poem in 230 verses which has come down to us under his name was probably the work of an Alexandrian Jew of the first century A.D.
gegenh=sqai: the force of the perfect is, ‘have proved themselves.’
sundiatri/bein tai=s a)llh/lwn a)noi/ais, ‘spend their time over one another's follies,’ i.e. in listening to each other's foolish talk. For sundiatri/bein see note on E. 76.
u(poqh/kas: see note on § 3.

ei)/ tis e)kle/ceie tw=n proexo/ntwn poihtw=n ta\s kaloume/nas gnw/mas, ‘if one were to pick out the so-called maxims of our distinguished poets,’ i.e. if a collection of gnomic sayings (gnwmologi/a) were made from well-known poets, i.e. from the tragic poets, as is clear from the contrast with the writings of the comic poets. In Latin we have a good example of a collection of sayings of this kind in the Sententiae of Publilius Syrus.
e)kei=noi: i.e. oi( proe/xontes poihtai/.

kwmw|di/as th=s faulota/ths: Isocr. had a very poor opinion of contemporary comedy; cp. de Pace 14 dhmokrati/as ou)/shs ou)k e)/sti parrhsi/a plh
 e)nqa/de (i.e. in the Ecclesia) me
 toi=s a)fronesta/tois kai\ mhde
 u(mw=n fronti/zousin, e)n de\ tw=| qea/trw| toi=s kwmw|dodidas ka/lois. The reason of his dislike of the comic writers was probably the fact that they caricatured him; cp. Strattis, Comicorum Atticorum fragmenta, ed. Kock, vol. i, p. 713, and Aristophanes, ib., p. 563.
tw=n ou(/tw texnikw=s pepoihme/nwn, ‘such skilful compositions’; for texnikw=s see note on E. 73.

The actions of most men are opposed to their best interests; they do not take pleasure in noble actions, just as they do not care for wholesome food, and they look upon those who do their duty as dull and painstaking. They consider it a trouble to look after their own private affairs, and prefer to discuss other people's business; they would rather suffer bodily sickness than undergo mental labour. Such men can take no pleasure in exhortation and instruction.
ei) q)e/loimen . . . eu(rh/somen: for this slightly irregular conditional sentence see note on E. 66 ti/na ga\r eu(rh/somen . . . ei) . . . skopoi=men;
ou)/te tw=n siti/wn xai/rontas kte(: for this analogy between choice of action and choice of diet cp. ad Dem. 45 (quoted in note on § 42) and de Pace 100.

ou)/te tw=n qremma/twn toi=s w)felimwta/tois: the reading qremma/twn (see critical note) is defended by Cobet (N. L. p. 154), who points out that Isocr. is here thinking of the useless animals, gamecocks, quails, &c., kept for sporting purposes (cp. Plato, Legg. 789 B).

karterikou/s: karterei=n has two meanings: (1) ‘to persevere (in some course)’; (2) ‘to hold out (against anything)’, so karteriko/s might mean either ‘plodding’ or ‘ascetic’; the latter perhaps is best here.
pro\s toi=s ei)rhme/nois, ‘in addition to what has been said,’ i.e. ‘in addition to the charges I have already brought against them’.
fqonou=si toi=s eu)= fronou=si: for the paronomasi/a cp. § 26 kthsame/nous . . . xrhsame/nous and note.
a(plou=s: like ‘simple’ in English, can be used (1) in a good sense, ‘open’, ‘guileless’, or (2) in a bad sense, ‘foolish’, ‘unintellectual’. The former is the meaning here and in N. C. 52.
ta\ sfe/ter' au)tw=n: au)tw=n is a possessive gen. carrying on and emphasizing the possessive idea contained in sfe/tera.
logizo/menoi, ‘if they take thought’; dialego/menoi, ‘conversing,’ so ‘gossiping’.
tw=n a)nagkai/wn, ‘the necessary duties of life’ (like tw=n deo/ntwn, § 45).

h)\ lhrou=ntas h)\ loidoroume/nous (see critical note), ‘either talking nonsense or using abusive language’. This is better than reading loidorou=ntas h)\ loidoroume/nous, ‘reviling or being reviled,’ since the middle rather than the active of loidorei=n is used.
e)n tai=s e)rhmi/ais, ‘in solitude,’ as opposed to e)n tai=s pro\s a)llh/lous sunousi/ais, ‘in the society of one another.’
eu)xome/nous, ‘indulging in vain wishes’ (F.).
tw=n e)no/xwn toi=s ei)rhme/nois, ‘those who are liable to my imputations.’ e)/noxos is originally a legal term ‘bound by’ (= e)nexo/menos), so, generally, ‘liable to.’

Those writers who wish to be read must introduce stories and fables, which are as popular as games and contests. This accounts for the popularity of Homer and the Tragedians. Homer told tales of the battles of gods and heroes, and the Tragedians brought actual contests before the eyes of their audience. The writer who can only offer good advice cannot compete with such attractions.
kexarisme/non, ‘acceptable.’ The perf. part. pass. of xari/zesqai is frequently used as an adj.; cp. Latin acceptus. The adverb is found in § 15.
a)kou/ontes me\n ga\r . . . a(mi/llas, ‘for they delight in listening to such things, just as they delight in looking at contests and races.’
a)mfote/rais tai=s i)de/ais tau/tais, ‘both these kinds (of attraction).’ For i)de/a see note on § 34.

oi( de\ tou\s mu/qous . . . kate/sthsan, ‘while the latter (i.e. the early writers of tragedy) have put the fables into the form of contests and actions,’ i.e. have represented on the stage the battles &c., described in the fables.
a)koustou\s . . . qeatou/s, ‘presented to our hearing . . . presented to our sight.’
toiou/twn ou)=n paradeigma/twn u(parxo/ntwn, ‘with such examples then, before us.’ For u(pa/rxein see note on E. 19.
de/deiktai, ‘it is clear’; see note on § 10.
o(/ti . . . a)fekte/on, ta\ de\ toiau=ta lekte/on: for the impersonal verbal construction see note on E. 7 ou) mh\n douleute/on.

It is your duty as a king to test men and actions by the advantage which they confer upon the state. Those who are engaged in philosophy, while differing as to the actual course of mental training to be pursued, are all agreed that an educated man must acquire the power of taking counsel from all available sources.

to
 ou)x e(/na tw=n pollw=n a)lla\ pollw=n basileu/onta: a good example of chiasmus; see note on E. 4 oi( de\ peri\ th
 mousikh
 kte(.
e)pi\ tw=n xrhsi/mwn, ‘in the light of what is expedient’; cp. E. 34 e)pi\ tou/twn skopw=men and note.
a)/llws t' e)peidh/: see note on E. 7.
oi( peri\ th\n filosofi/an o)/ntes: cp. oi( peri\ th\n mousikh/n, E. 4 and note. For filosofi/a see Introd. p. 14.

dia\ tw=n e)ristikw=n lo/gwn, ‘by disputations on controversial topics.’ e)ristikoi\ lo/goi are literally ‘wrangling discussions’, so ‘disputations’. Protagoras is said to have been an upholder of this form of mental gymnastic, and to have written a book called h( e)ristikw=n te/xnh. Isocr. seems to have approved of such discussions (cp. Panath. 26 e)painw= . . . tou\s dialo/gous tou\s e)ristikou\s kaloume/nous), though he thinks that the younger generation in his own day was too fond of them, an opinion which he repeats in Antidos. 261. We are told (Ps.-Plut. vit. Isocr. p. 837) that Isocrates was the first to distinguish between e)ristikoi/ and politikoi\ lo/goi.

tw=n politikw=n: sc. lo/gwn, ‘political discussions’; see note on politiko/s, E. 10. Isocr. praises this form of mental training in contr. Sophist. 21 sunaskh=sai ma/list' a)\n oi)=mai th\n tw=n lo/gwn tw=n politikw=n e)pime/leian.
tou\s au(toi=s plhsia/zontas: i.e. their pupils.
to\n kalw=s pepaideume/non, ‘a well-educated man.’
e)c e(ka/stou tou/twn, ‘from all these different sources,’ i.e. ta\ gumna/sia ta\ th=s yuxh=s which he has described.

p.title: Test men by principles which do not admit of dispute, observing them when they are giving advice on difficult points, or, failing that, when they are giving judgement on general topics. Reject
p.hi: those who show that they cannot grasp a position; honour those who show intelligence and foresight. Those who can benefit your understanding will make you a great king.

div2.p: a)fe/menon, ‘avoiding,’ lit. ‘letting go from oneself’, followed by the genitive in Attic Greek.

e)pi\ tou= sunomologoume/nou lamba/nein au)tw=n to\n e)/legxon, ‘test them in the light of generally admitted principles.’ For o(mologei=n see note on E. 44 o(mologi/a, and for this use of e)pi/ cp. e)pi\ tw=n xrhsi/mwn, § 50 and note.
au)tw=n: i.e. those whose advice Nicocles is thinking of taking, or perhaps quite generally of ‘mankind’.

ma/lista me\n e)pi\ tw=n kairw=n kte(, ‘if possible, you should observe them when they are giving advice to suit special occasions.’ ma/lista often introduces the preferable of two alternatives. For kairo/s see note on E. 31.
ei) de\ mh/, kai\ kaq' o(/lwn tw=n pragma/twn le/gontas, ‘and failing that, when they are speaking on general topics.’
a)podoki/maze, ‘reject (after scrutiny)’; see note on dokimasi/as, § 27.
o( mhde\n w)\n au)to\s xrh/simos, ‘if a man is of no use in himself.’ mhde/n is an adverbial accusative qualifying xrh/simos.
o(ra=n ple/on ti tw=n a)/llwn: we should say ‘see farther than others’.
qera/peue: see note on qerapeu/ein, E. 28.
turannikw/taton, ‘most worthy of a monarch’; see note on turanniko/s, E. 46, and cp. basilikwta/tous, N. C. 10.

I have given you the best advice I can; this is my gift to you. The usual gifts made to princes cost more to the recipient than if he bought them in the open market, and in time perish; but good advice, however much used, will never be the worse for wear.
o(/per ei)=pon a)rxo/menos: i.e. in § 1. For a)rxo/menos see note on E. 63 teleutw=n.

a)lla\ toiau/tas . . . katatri/yeis, ‘but such gifts, that, however much you use them (lit. if you use them very much) and if you use them every day (lit. if you never leave out a day), you will never wear them out.’

Some people find fault with oratory and say that it is used for selfish ends. But men praise those who act rightly, so why should they abuse those who speak well? We ought not to blame circumstances which enable men to advance their interests by acting virtuously; we should keep our condemnation for those who, while their actions are wicked, use words in order to deceive.
tou\s lo/gous, ‘speeches’, ‘oratorical displays’, as in E. 4, 76.
tou\s filosofou=ntas: i.e. in particular those who cultivate eloquence which is a part of filosofi/a.
pleoneci/as, ‘selfish ends’; see note on pleonektei=n, E. 11.
diatriba/s: see note on diatri/bein, E. 31.
ta\ peri\ tou\s qeou/s: adverbial accusative; cp. ta\ pro\s tou\s qeou/s, ad N. 20 and note; a similar phrase occurs in ad Dem. 13 eu)se/bei ta\ pro\s tou\s qeou/s.
e)/latton e)/xwmen, ‘come off worse than.’ e)/latton e)/xein is the opposite of pleonektei=n.

o(/pws a)\n . . . dia/gwmen: a)/n is sometimes found in final clauses in conjunction with o(/pws and the subjunctive (first found in Aeschylus), also with w(s in Xenophon (though never in Isocrates), but in no case with i(/na. The a)/n seems to add little to the meaning; it is never found in negative final clauses.
w(s meta\ plei/stwn: for meq' w(s plei/stwn.
to\n bi/on dia/gwmen: see note on E. 24.
w(/ste: a connecting particle, as in ad N. 11.

w(/st' ou) kathgorhte/on kte(, ‘so we ought not to find fault with the circumstances which enable a man to advance his own interests while practising virtue, but rather with those individuals who in action do wrong or employ words in order to deceive, thus putting them to a wrongful use.’

p.title: If eloquence is to be blamed because some men misuse it, the same applies to wealth and strength and courage, which are also in themselves excellent things. Yet we do not condemn strength, because one man may unjustly strike another; the blame is put not on the qualities themselves, but on those who misuse them.

div2.p: qauma/zw de\ tw=n . . . e)xo/ntwn, o(/pws ou) . . . le/gousin: lit. ‘but I am astonished in those who hold this opinion how it is that they do not abuse wealth’, &c., we should say, ‘I am astonished that those who hold this opinion do not abuse wealth,’ &c. qauma/zein, when followed by a personal object, can take (1) acc. of person, (2) gen. of person and acc. of thing, (3) gen. of person and a dependent clause, as here.
a)lla\ ga/r: see note on ad N. 41.

ou) di/kaion kte(: strength and wealth and courage are good things, but they may be used to do harm (e.g. a strong man may use his strength to strike another man unjustly); we must not blame the strength itself or the wealth, which has brought a man to disaster, but the individual who has made a wrong use of his advantages. Aristotle frequently insists on the harm which ta\ a)gaqa/ can do, e.g. in Eth. Nic. 1094^{b} 17 toiau/thn de/ tina pla/nhn e)/xei kai\ ta)gaqa\ dia\ to\ polloi=s sumbai/nein bla/bas a)p' au)tw=n: h)/dh ga/r tines a)pw/lonto dia\ plou=ton, e(/teroi de\ di) a)ndrei/an. He explains the apparent contradiction by saying that things which are in themselves (a(plw=s) good, may incidentally (kata\ sumbebhko/s) cause harm. We may compare Seneca, Ep. v. 9 multa bona nostra nobis nocent.
metafe/rein, ‘transfer’, ‘shift’. For the meaning of meta/ in composition with verbs see note on metapeptw/kasin, E. 50.

Those who find fault with the exercise of the function of speech are blaming a faculty in man which is most productive of good. It differentiates us from the beasts and has done more than anything to foster civilization. It is the faculty which has enabled man to make laws, to educate himself, to inquire into the unknown, and to deliberate on matters of importance. In short it is the guide and inspiration of deed and thought, and to speak evil of philosophers and educators, who make the greatest use of it, is almost as wicked as to commit sacrilege.
a)melh/santes . . . peri\ e(ka/stou diori/zesqai, ‘not taking the trouble to define things clearly.’
tou=ton to\n tro/pon: adverbial acc., ‘in this manner.’
a(/pantas tou\s lo/gous, ‘speech in general.’
diafe/romen: on the meanings of this word see note on E. 14.
eu)pori/ais, ‘advantages.’
e)ggenome/nou d' h(mi=n tou= pei/qein kte(, ‘but since there is implanted in us the power to persuade one another and to make clear,’ &c.
h(ma=s au)tou/s: reflexive for reciprocal; cp. E. 53, 57, and ad N. 17.
lo/gos: it may be noted how closely allied are the two meanings of this word (1) ‘speech’, and (2) ‘reason’, ‘reason’ being the power of the mind as manifested in speech.
dokima/zomen: see note on dokimasi/a, ad N. 27.
tou= fronei=n eu)=: for order instead of the more natural tou= eu)= fronei=n, which would involve a hiatus, cp. E. 58 metacu\ pa/sxwn eu)=.
yuxh=s: see note on E. 23.
ei)/dwlon, ‘image’, ‘reflexion’.
peri\ tw=n a)mfisbhthsi/mwn a)gwnizo/meqa, ‘we discuss matters which admit of dispute.’

pi/stesin: here a rhetorical technical term, ‘arguments’, ‘proofs’, lit. ‘means of persuasion’. Aristotle (Rhet. 1355^{a} 4 ff.) defines pi/stis as a proof which is of a moral rather than a scientific kind, the latter being called a)po/deicis.
r(htorikou/s, ‘clever orators.’ For the force of adjectives in -iko/s see note on dhmotiko/s, E. 46.
au)toi\ pro\s au(tou/s, ‘in their own minds.’
sullh/bdhn, ‘in short,’ an adv. formed from the stem of the verb sullamba/nein; cp. kru/bdhn from kru/ptein and spora/dhn from spei/rein.

duna/mews: here ‘capacity’, ‘faculty’. du/namis from meaning ‘power’ comes to mean ‘the power to produce a certain effect’, so ‘capacity’. In Aristotle by a further refinement of meaning du/namis is a ‘capability’, a ‘potentiality’, or power which has virtual existence but is not actually brought into play, as opposed to e)ne/rgeia, a capability which is put into action.
a)lo/gws = a)/neu lo/gou, ‘without the assistance of speech.’
tou\s ei)s ta\ tw=n qew=n e)camarta/nontas: i.e. those who rob or profane the property of the gods.

p.title: I approve of any discourse which is beneficial, particularly if it treats of moral questions and the relations between kings and subjects. We have already heard Isocrates on the relation of rulers to their subjects; I will now treat of the duties of subjects towards their rulers. When you have heard my views, I shall have the right of censuring those who do not carry out my wishes.

div2.p: a)pode/xomai, ‘welcome,’ as in E. 2.
kai\ kata\ mikro/n: see note on ou) kata\ mikro/n, E. 59.
ou) mh\n a)lla/: see note on E. 33.
basilikwta/tous, ‘most worthy of a king’; in ad N. 53 turannikw/taton is used in exactly the same sense.
e)pithdeuma/twn, ‘pursuits’, so ‘habits of daily life’, ‘moral conduct’ (F.).
politeiw=n: see note on E. 46 e(ka/sths th=s politei/as.
to\n me\n ou)=n e(/teron: sc. lo/gon, i. e. the speech of Isocrates ad Nicoclem.
to\n d' e)xo/menon: sc. lo/gon, ‘the following discourse’; cp. e)k tw=n e)xome/nwn, E. 33 and note.
u(perbalou/menos: see note on E. I u(perbolh/n.

prosh=kon: acc. absolute—a construction usually found with impersonal verbs or verbs used impersonally in the passive, e.g. de/on, ‘it being necessary,’ prostetagme/non, ‘it having been ordered’: w(s is practically always added if a subject is expressed; cp. § 48 w(s to\ su/mpan e(/con.
diama/rtoite th=s e)mh=s gnw/mhs, ‘you should mistake my sentiments’ (F.).
My exhortations will have more weight, if I prove to you, firstly, that our political conditions are ideal, and secondly, that I hold rule by every divine and human right.
parakale/sai: see note on E. 28.

ei) peri\ to\ sumbouleu/ein mo/non genoi/mhn, ‘if I were to devote myself solely to giving advice.’ For this common use of peri/ in Isocr. cp. E. 4 oi( peri\ th\n mousikh\n kai\ ta\s a)/llas a)gwni/as o)/ntes.
tau=ta = tau/tas ta\s sumbouli/as.
a)pallagei/hn: here a)palla/ssw in the pass. is used absolutely, ‘leave off’, ‘desist’.

ei) proepidei/caimi . . . th\n politei/an . . . w(s a)/cio/n e)stin kte(.: here after a verb of showing the subject of the dependent clause is anticipated as the object of the principal verb. For a similar construction after a verb of knowing cp. E. 6 ou(\s ou)k i)/sasin ei) gego/nasin, and note.
a)/cio/n e)stin a)gapa=n: for a)gapa=n see note on E. 74.
e)/peiq), ‘and secondly.’
ou) parano/mws ou)d' a)llotri/an, ‘not by lawlessness and usurpation’ (F.). For this coupling together of an adverb and an adjective see note on E. 37 kai\ plei=stoi kai\ ma/lista.
o(si/ws kai\ dikai/ws: the same phrase occurs in E. 26 o(si/ws kai\ dikai/ws labei=n th\n a)rxh/n.

Monarchy has great advantages. It is monstrous that the good and bad should receive the same treatment; yet oligarchies and democracies aim at equality among citizens, which clearly gives an advantage to the wicked. Monarchies, on the other hand, reward according to merit. Again absolute rulers can judge men's characters better, and a wise man will choose to live where his good qualities will obtain recognition. Monarchies too, are milder, because it is easier to know, and so to obey, the will of one ruler than that of many.
u(potiqe/menos: see note on ad N. 3 u(poqh/kas.
to\ diwri/sqai peri\ tou/twn kte(, ‘that there should be distinctions laid down between such people, and that persons who behave in different ways should not meet with the same treatment.’
tw=n politeiw=n: here ‘political rights’; see note on E. 46.
tou=t' eu)dokimei= par) au)tai=s, h)/n, ‘this principle is held in honour amongst them, that,’ &c.
deute/rw| de\ . . . kata\ to\n au)to\n lo/gon, ‘and proportionately to the second best after him, and the third and fourth best and so on.’ deute/rw|, ‘second (in point of excellence).’
to/ ge bou/lhma th=s politei/as, ‘the intention of this form of government.’ Jebb compares Plato, Leg. 769 D a)=r' ou) toiou=ton dokei= soi to\ tou= nomoqe/tou bou/lhm) ei)=nai.
diora=n: see note on dio/ra, ad N. 28.
tw=n eu)= fronou/ntwn: with ti/s, ‘what man of sense?’
e)n h(=| mh\ dialh/sei xrhsto\s w)/n, ‘in which his excellent qualities will not fail to be observed.’ dialh/sei, on the meaning and constructions of lanqa/nein see note on E. 42.
ma=llon h)\ fe/resqai kte(, ‘rather than be carried away with the crowd without his real character being recognized.’
a)lla\ mh/n: introducing a new point, ‘then again.’
gnw/mh|, ‘will.’
ma=llon: redundant.

Thus monarchy is the pleasantest, justest, and mildest form of government; it is also more efficient in deliberation and action. Those who hold office for one year only have to retire before they have mastered their duties; a monarch has the advantage of continuous experience. Again, he knows that he has to superintend everything; the oligarchic and democratic ruler has colleagues, and much remains undone because each thinks the other is doing it.
ou) mh\n a)lla/: see note on E. 33.
dia\ tou/twn: i. e. the reasons already given.
sunidei=n: lit. ‘see together’, so ‘see at a glance’.

peri\ de\ tw=n loipw=n kte(, ‘but in the other points we should best see how superior monarchies are in respect of necessary deliberation and action, if we set side by side and try to examine one by one the most important spheres of action’ (i. e. as performed by monarchy and by other forms of government).
i)diw=tai gi/gnontai, ‘pass into private life again.’
oi( d' a)ei\ kte(: i. e. oi( mo/narxoi.
a)ll' ou)=n, ‘at any rate.’
ei)s a)llh/lous a)poble/pontes, ‘because each looks to another to do them,’ i. e. what is not a particular person's duty is no one's duty.
o)ligwrou=sin: see note on E. 41.
oi( e)n tai=s o)ligarxi/ais, ‘those who hold office in oligarchies,’ or perhaps simply ‘those who live under oligarchies’.
ta\s pro\s sfa=s au)tou\s filotimi/as, ‘their rival ambitions.’ sfa=s au)tou/s = a)llh/lous as often, see note on E. 53.

p.title: In oligarchies and democracies the rulers have private interests, further they only meet occasionally and opportunities for action are missed; monarchs are continually occupied in the public interest. Again, the former are jealous and wish to exalt themselves at the expense of their predecessors and successors, the latter seek the good will of all. But the greatest difference is that monarchs treat public affairs as their own concern, other rulers transact them as if they
p.hi: were other people's business, and they choose their advisers accordingly.

div2.p: u(steri/zousi: see note on E. 73.
diaferome/nous: see note on E. 14.
a)podedeigme/nwn, ‘appointed’, ‘fixed’.
e)pi\ tai=s pra/cesin o)/ntes, ‘being engaged in their duties.’
dusmenw=s e)/xousi: used absolutely, ‘have bitter feelings.’
tou\s e)f' au(toi=s, ‘their successors,’ but tou\s e)f' au(tw=n (E. 5), ‘their contemporaries.’
to\ de\ me/giston: toi=s ga/r: see note on E. 8 shmei=on de\ me/giston . . . ga/r.

tou\s e)n toi=s o)/xlois ei)pei=n . . . e)pistame/nous: the reference is to the r(h/tores or professional orators who spoke in the Ecclesia. Isocrates, like Demosthenes, realized and continually emphasized the evil influence of this class on Athenian politics; cp. Panath. 12 pa/ntes i)/sasi tw=n me\n r(hto/rwn tou\s pollou\s ou)x u(pe\r tw=n th=| po/lei sumfero/ntwn, a)ll' u(pe\r w(=n au)toi\ lh/yesqai prosdokw=si, dhmhgorei=n tolmw=ntas.

In war too a monarch has great advantages. He can raise troops without attracting attention and surprise his foes, and he can win them over by persuasion or coercion. The success of monarchies in war can be illustrated from the Persian Empire and from the rule of Dionysius of Syracuse. Even the Spartans and Carthaginians prefer a monarchy in time of war, and Athens has always been more successful under one than under many generals.

e)n toi=s e)gkukli/ois, ‘matters of ordinary routine.’ e)gku/klios, lit. ‘recurring in a circle’, so ‘periodical’ (as in de Pace 87 e(\n h)=n tou=to tw=n e)gkukli/wn, tafa\s poiei=n kaq' e(/kaston to\n e)niauto/n), so ‘constantly recurring’.
a)lla\ kai\ ta\s e)n tw=| pole/mw| kte(, ‘but they also possess (lit. have seized) all the advantages in war.’ For pleoneci/as see note on E. 11 pleonektou/shs.

laqei=n kai\ fqh=nai, ‘to escape notice and anticipate the foe.’ The correction of o)fqh=nai (see critical note) to fqh=nai gives much better sense, and does away with the hiatus; if o)fqh=nai is kept we shall have to translate ‘to escape notice or attract observation’ (F.), which has little point. For the combination of lanqa/nein and fqa/nein
cp. E. 42 mh/te tou\s e)pibouleu/ontas au)tw=| fqa/nein mh/te tou\s e)pieikei=s o)/ntas lanqa/nein.

para\ de\ tw=n e)kpri/asqai: the usual meaning of e)kpri/asqai is ‘to buy off’, ‘redeem’ (cp. Antiph. 136. 36 xrh/masi ki/ndunon e)kpri/asqai). Here, however, it must mean merely ‘to buy’, i.e. ‘get (what they want) by purchase’, a sense in which e)cwnei=sqai, which supplies the present of e)kpri/asqai, is found in Herodot. i. 196.

tai=s a)/llais qerapei/ais, ‘by various services.’ a)/llais is here used in a slightly illogical manner, since tou\s me\n pei=sai kte(. can hardly be called qerapei=ai: cp. Xen. Anab. i. 5. 5 ou) ga\r h)=n xo/rtos ou)de\ a)/llo de/ndron ou)de/n. For qerapei/a see note on E. 28 qerapeu/ein.
tou=to me\n . . . tou=to de/: see note on E. 14.

th\n tw=n *persw=n du/namin: the Persian Empire owed its greatness to the military genius of Cyrus and the organizing power of Darius. The folly of Xerxes put an end to all hope of expansion to the West, but did not materially affect the position of Persia in the East. Alexander the Great conquered Persia, as he conquered every other power with which he came into contact; but the Romans could not make much impression on the Persian monarchy, particularly under the Empire.
thlikau/thn to\ me/geqos: see note on E. 19.

*dionu/sion: Dionysius I of Syracuse owed his rise to the lead which he took against the Carthaginians, when in 406 B.C. they had already conquered Camarina and Gela and were threatening Syracuse. He is therefore a particularly good instance of a tyrant whose success was due to his military ability; he ruled, however, on democratic principles (pisteuqei\s w(s dhmotiko\s w)/n, Aristot. Pol. 1305^{a} 28).
paralabw/n: see note on E. 35.
a)na/staton: lit. of persons ‘made to arise’, so ‘driven from house and home’, hence of countries and cities ‘laid waste’.

*karxhdoni/ous kai\ *lakedaimoni/ous: Aristotle similarly classes the Carthaginians and Spartans together: politeu/esqai de\ dokou=si kai\ *karxhdo/nioi kalw=s . . . ma/lista d' e)/nia paraplhsi/ws toi=s *la/kwsin (Pol. 1272^{b} 24), tou\s de\ basilei=s (e)/xousin oi( *karxhdo/nioi) kai\ th\n gerousi/an a)na/logon toi=s e)kei= basileu=si kai\ ge/rousin (ib. 37). The Spartan kings belonged to two families, the Agidae, who claimed Achaean descent, and the Eurypontidae, who were perhaps Dorian. In
historic times their military functions were so preponderant that Aristotle (Pol. 1285^{a} 6) describes the kingship as strathgi/a tis au)tokra/twr kai\ a)i+/dios, ‘an absolute and perpetual generalship.’ Their official title bagoi/ (‘leaders’) also indicates their chief function. The two chief magistrates at Carthage were known as ‘suffetes’ (probably the same word as the Hebrew ‘shophetim’, ‘judges’). They seem to have been chosen from a limited number of leading families.

tou\s a)/rista tw=n a)/llwn politeuome/nous: Sparta appealed to the Greek thinker as the one state in Hellas which realized his ideal of permanence, which was secured by the perfect balance of the elements which composed it.

a)/rista tw=n a)/llwn: lit. ‘best of all others’ (which is illogical), so ‘far better than any other state’. The superlative is often used, where a comparative might be expected, to express a superlative degree of superiority: cp. the well-known instance in Soph. Antig. 100 ka/lliston tw=n pro/teron fa/os, ‘light far fairer than all former lights.’
th\n po/lin: i.e. Athens. tw=n *)aqhnai/wn is added by some MSS. (see critical note).
o(/tan me\n pollou\s e)kpe/myh| strathgou/s, a)tuxou=san: e.g. at Aegospotami, where six generals were in command, and on the Sicilian expedition, when Athens sent out three commanders.

Thus it is clear that monarchy is the most efficient form of government. It is said that even the gods are under the kingship of Zeus; even if this were untrue, yet the fact that we imagine that the gods are under a monarchy is an admission that we consider it the best form of government.

fai/nontai ga\r . . . pra/ttontes: oi(/ te dia\ te/lous turanneuo/menoi, oi(/ te kalw=s o)ligarxou/menoi, oi(/ te misou=ntes ta\s turanni/das are all subjects of fai/nontai, with which the participles e)/xontes, kaqista/ntes, and pra/ttontes are to be closely taken. oi(/ te kalw=s o)ligarxou/menoi are subdivided by oi( me/n, oi( de/, which may be translated ‘in some cases’, ‘in other cases’.

dia\ te/lous: this phrase can mean either (1) ‘continually’, or (2) ‘completely’. The former gives the best sense here, and is usually
the meaning of the phrase in Isocrates; cp. Phil. 24 dia\ te/lous, and de Pace 17.
peri\ a(/: i.e. e)n e)kei/nois peri\ a(/. For the hiatus see note on E. 3 peri\ au(tw=n.
peri\ w(=n: see last note.
kata/stasin, ‘state of affairs’; cp. § 55 th\n parou=san kata/stasin.

So much must suffice to prove the superiority of monarchy, a subject which might be discussed at far greater length. It remains for me to point out that I have an indisputable right to rule as the direct descendant of Teucer, the original colonizer of Salamis, and as son of Evagoras, who drove out the Phoenicians and re-established the family on the throne.
ou) mh\n a)lla/: see note on E. 33.
a)poxrw/ntws ... proshko/ntws: adverbs formed from the participles of the impersonal verbs a)po/xrh and prosh/kei: cp. peplanhme/nws, E. 43 and note.
*teu=kros: see E. 17, 18.
paralabw/n: see note on E. 35.
*eu)ago/ras: see E. passim, and for the termination of the Phoenician occupation of Salamis ib. 19, 20, and 27-33.
tosou=ton mete/sthsen w(/ste, ‘caused such a change of affairs that ...’ On meta/ in composition see note on E. 50 metapeptw/kasin.

w(=nper h)=n th
 a)rxh/n: tou/tous is the antecedent, ‘those who originally possessed it.’ Cp. Andoc. de Pace 20 e)ch=n ga au)toi=s kai\ th
 a)rxh
 e)w=sin *)orxomeni/ous au)tono/mous ei)rh/nhn a)/gein. th
 a)rxh/n is an adverbial accusative; contrast the sense of a)rxh/, ‘beginning,’ with a)rxh/, ‘rule’ (th
 a)rxh/n above).
I must now show that I am personally worthy of the kingship. Firstly, I possess the virtues of temperance and justice.
w(=n: by attraction for e)kei/nwn a(/.
thlikau/ths: sc. timh=s, ‘my present dignity great though it is,’ lit ‘such great honour’.
to\ kaq' au(ta/s, ‘in themselves,’ adverbial acc.; cp. ta\ pro\s tou\s qeou/s, ad N. 20 and note.
ta\s xrh/seis tw=n pragma/twn, ‘ways of dealing with circumstances’; cp. xrh=sqai toi=s pra/gmasi, E. 55, ad N. 35.
ta\s me\n mh\ metexou/sas: these words must refer to ta\s fu/seis kai\ ta\s duna/meis kai\ ta\s xrh/seis, though they would more naturally refer to fu/seis only.
tou/twn tw=n i)dew=n, ‘these qualities’; see note on ad N. 34.
e)kei/nois: dat. after th=s au)th=s: see note on E. 27.

My justice may be seen in my behaviour at my accession. The treasury was empty and everything in confusion; but I avoided banishments, executions and confiscations. Greece was inaccessible owing to the war and we were harassed on all sides, the inhabitants of Cyprus and the Great King being alike hostile. By zealous service to the latter and justice towards the former, I conciliated them both. I have never coveted the territory of my neighbours, but have preferred to rule my own people justly rather than increase my power by injustice. In a word I have done no man wrong, but conferred many benefits upon my subjects and upon the Greeks.
e)kei=qen: see note on E. 11.
ta\ basi/leia: usually means ‘the palace’, but here ‘the royal treasury’; to\ basi/leion is found in this sense in Herodot. ii. 149.
e)k panto\s tro/pou: see note on E. 39.
th\n fu/sin th\n au(tw=n, ‘their natural inclinations.’
ou)d' u(f) e(no/s: a stronger form of u(p' ou)deno/s: cp. ou)de\ peri\ e(no/s, E. 52, and ou)de\ pro\s e(/n, E. 44.
e)pidou=nai: see note on e)pido/seis, E. 7.
proshne/xqhn, ‘I behaved.’
e)pi\ th=s e)mh=s basilei/as: see note on tou\s e)f' au(tw=n, E. 5.
dia\ to\n po/lemon: i.e. the wars at sea between the Athenians and Spartans, and on land between the Spartans and Thebans.
sulwme/nwn h(mw=n: the context seems to show that these words refer to reprisals on the people of Salamis caused by monetary difficulties with their neighbours.
ta\ plei=sta tou/twn die/lusa, ‘I settled most of these claims.’ The sense of tou/twn has to be supplied from sulwme/nwn h(mw=n.
basile/ws: for the omission of the article see note on E. 20 basilei= tw=| mega/lw|.
tw=| me\n lo/gw| dihllagme/nou: i.e. by the peace concluded by Evagoras in 380 B.C. after ten years of warfare.

th=| d' a)lhqei/a| traxe/ws e)/xontos: in 384 Lysias warned the Greeks
at Olympia that in spite of the Peace of Antalcidas the Great King was a constant menace to Greece; much more would he be a source of danger to his neighbours in Cyprus.
a)mfo/tera tau=ta katepra/u+na, ‘I appeased both these sources of hostility’ (F.). a)mfote/rous tou/tous might have been expected; for the use of neuter for masculine see note on E. 72 ou)de/n.
tosou/tou de/w: see note on E. 21.
e(/teroi me/n, . . . e)gw\ de/: we should say, ‘while others . . ., I . . .’

a)pote/mnontai th=s gh=s, ‘cut off and appropriate portions of their territory,’ a)pote/mnontai is a good example of the use of the middle voice, ‘to do something for one's self.’ th=s gh=s is a partitive genitive; cp. Theocr. xvii. 86 kai\ mh\n *foini/kas a)pote/mnetai *)arrabi/as te.
pleonektei=n: see note on E. 11.
didome/nhn, ‘when it was offered to me.’ There is no evidence as to any offer of territory made to Nicocles, but we know from E. 47 that his father ruled practically the whole of Cyprus.
th=s u(parxou/shs: gen. after the comparative idea contained in pollaplasi/an. For u(pa/rxein see note on E. 19.
a)/llws te kai/: see note on E. 7 a)/llws t' e)peidh\ kai/.
me/ga fronou=ntas e)pi/: see note on E. 45.
xrhma/twn . . . krei/ttous, ‘superior to considerations of money,’ lit. ‘stronger than money’; similarly xrhma/twn h(/sswn (Theopomp. ap. Athen. 252. 6) is ‘a slave to money’.
toiau/tas u(perbola\s e)/xein ei)pei=n, ‘can use such extravagant language about themselves.’ For u(perbolh/ see note on E. 1.

As to temperance, my private life has always been beyond reproach. I have tried to set an example in this respect to my subjects, and have felt that it is wrong for kings to expect their subjects to lead an orderly life while they themselves do not live temperately. My life is a condemnation of those who, quite upright in other respects, fail in their duties towards their wives and family. My children can all claim a pure descent on their father's and their mother's side from the hero Aeacus and from Zeus.

w(s porrwta/tw . . . tw=n toiou/twn u(poyiw=n, ‘as far as possible from such suspicions.’ The genitive is due to the idea of separation in porrwta/tw. Adverbs in -w generally keep this termination in the
comparative and superlative; cp. a)/nw, a)nwte/rw, a)nwta/tw: the comparative porrwte/rw is found in Phil. 122.
filei= to\ plh=qos kte(: for the sentiment cp. ad N. 31 to\ th=s po/lews o(/lhs h)=qos o(moiou=tai toi=s a)/rxousi, and note.

kai\ deina\ poiei=n, o(/soi: an antecedent such as e)kei/nous must be supplied on the subject of the infin. poiei=n. For the sentiment cp. ad N. l. c mh\ tou\s a)/llous a)ci/ou kosmi/ws zh=n, tou\s de\ basilei=s a)ta/ktws, a)lla\ th\n sautou= swfrosu/nhn para/deigma toi=s a)/llois kaqi/sth.
tw=n a)rxome/nwn: see note on pisteu/qeis, E. 19.
tw=n a)/llwn pra/cewn . . . e)gkratei=s, ‘masters of their other actions.’
tw=n e)piqumiw=n . . . h(ttwme/nous: see note on E. 44.
karterei=n: see note on ad N. 32.
ste/rgousin oi(=s e)/pracan: by attraction for e)kei/nois a(\ e)/pracan. The dative after ste/rgein is less common than the accusative.
u(f' w(=n au)toi\ mhde\n a)ciou=si lupei=sqai, ‘whom they expect never to cause them any pain.’
koinwni/as, ‘relations.’
mei/zous: equivalent to mei/zonos a)ci/ai, ‘more precious.’
lanqa/nousin . . . e)gkatalei/pontes, ‘are, without realizing it, storing up for themselves.’ For lanqa/nein see note on E. 42.

dia/gein: here transitive governing ta\s po/leis, ‘manage’, ‘rule’. The ordinary use of the word is either (1) literal ‘lead through’ (as in E. 30), or (2) with or without to\n bi/on, ‘to spend time’, ‘live’ (see note on E. 24).
toi=s plei/stois: dative after th\n au)th/n, ‘the same as the majority.’
semnote/ras: see note on semno/taton, E. 40.
a)nenegkei=n, ‘trace back’; Latin referre.
*ai)aki/das: Aeacus, a descendant of Zeus, was father of Telamon, the father of Teucer (o( tou= ge/nous h(mw=n a)rxhgo/s, § 28); cp. E. 14 ff.

p.title: I have been influenced by the realization that justice and temperance are only found in the best man. Virtues have a close relationship to circumstances. I exercised justice in a time of financial difficulty, moderation in a position of power, and temperance in the years of my youth. You are my witnesses and know that I am telling the truth. Virtues are all the more valuable and more likely to be permanent, when they are the outcome of reason.
After hearing my discourse you will have no excuse for failing to carry out my wishes with willing obedience.

div2.p: tw=n kalw=n ka)gaqw=n: see note on E. 51.
me/ros . . . me/testi: me/ros is pleonastic as in ad N. 30.
perittote/rws: for this termination of the comparative adverb see note on E. 5 filotimote/rws.
ta\s e)pi\ toi=s e)/rgois, ‘those concerned with actions’; for this force of e)pi/ with the dative cp. Paneg. 142 to\ me\n e)p' e)kei/nw|, ‘as far as he was concerned.’
dokima/zein: see note on ad N. 27 dokimasi/as.
e)n tai=s au)tai=s i)de/ais: see note on ad N. 34 a)mfote/rais tai=s i)de/ais.
e)n tai=s tw=n newte/rwn h(liki/ais: tw=n newte/rwn is masc., cp. e)k ne/wn. Isocr. almost always uses the comparative rather than the positive of ne/os. For h(liki/a see note on h(likiwtw=n, E. 22.
kataleifqei/s, ‘left’ at his father's death.

tou/twn d' a)mfote/rwn e)kra/thsa, ‘I proved my possession’ (this is the force of the aorist) ‘of both these virtues,’ i.e. dikaiosu/nh and swfrosu/nh: cp. Hel. 38 krath/sasan de\ toiau/ths a)reth=s kai\ swfrosu/nhs.
tau=t' e)n e(te/rois me\n i)/sws a)\n w)/knoun ei)pei=n: a present unfulfilled condition, the protasis of which is contained in the words e)n e(te/rois (= ei) e)n e(te/rois e)/legon).

w(s ou)k a)
 pisteuqei/s: w(s with a participle often replaces a causal clause expressing a reason present in the mind of the subject of the principal verb: here w(s ou)k a)
 pisteuqei/s is equivalent to nomi/zwn o(/ti ou)k a)
 e)pisteu/qhn, the protasis of the condition being supplied by e)k tw=n legome/nwn, ‘as a result of my words’ (= ei) tau=ta e)/leca).
meta\ logismou=, ‘in obedience to reason’ (F.).

tuxo/n: acc. absolute, lit. ‘it having happened’, so ‘if it so happened’, ‘perhaps’; cp. Paneg. 171 tuxo\n me\n ga\r a)/n ti sunepe/ranan, ‘for they might perhaps have accomplished something.’ For other examples of the acc. absolute see note on § 11 prosh=kon.
oi( de\ pro\s tw=| pefuke/nai kai\ diegnwko/tes, ‘but those who, in addition to their natural inclination, have also a reasoned conviction.’
e)n tau/th| th=| ta/cei diamenou=sin, ‘will remain firm in the position which they have taken up.’ ta/cis is here a military metaphor.
e(ko/ntas kai\ proqu/mws: for adjective and adverb coupled together cp. § 13 ou) parano/mws ou)d' a)llotri/an.

Each of you has his appointed duties, which must not be neglected; individually they may seem insignificant, but collectively they are all-important. The affairs of the state are as important as your own private affairs. Behave towards others as you would wish me to behave towards you. A good reputation is more precious than wealth. Do not look upon spending money as a loss and receiving it as a gain; both spending and saving are good if the circumstances and motives are right.
e)f' oi(=s e)fe/sthken: an antecedent must be supplied from e)f' oi(=s as the object of pra/ttein, ‘any duties which he is appointed to perform.’
kaq' o(po/teron ga\r . . . tou/twn, ‘for in whatever of such duties.’
e)lli/phte: used absolutely, ‘fail’, ‘fall short’; cp. ad N. 33 e)llei/pein ai(rou= kai\ mh\ pleona/zein.
mhdeno\s o)ligwrei=te: note that the gnomic character of this and the following sentences is marked by the omission of connecting particles.

u(polamba/nontes w(s ou) para\ tou=t' e)sti/n: lit. ‘under the idea that it does not depend on this’; instead of ou) we should expect ou)de/n, ‘that nothing depends on this,’ but the subject is indefinite as often in English. It is, I think, impossible to supply to\ su/mpan from the next clause, as Auger proposed to do. Lange well translates quod in eo res non sita est. For this use of para/ cp. Archid. 52 u(po\ pa/ntwn a)\n w(mologei=to para\ tou=ton gene/sqai th\n swthri/an.
a)ll' w(s par) e(/kaston . . . peri\ au)tw=n, ‘but perform your duties with zeal remembering that, as the parts are, so will the whole be good or bad.’
w(s . . . to\ su/mpan e(/con: acc. absolute here with a subject instead of being impersonal, see note on prosh=kon, § 11. For w(s with the participle see note on § 46 w(s ou)k a)\n pisteuqei/s.
mhde\n h(=tton . . . h)/, ‘just as carefully as.’
tw=n e)mw=n . . . tw=n u(mete/rwn: genitive after kh/desqe.
u(mete/rwn au)tw=n: au)tw=n is genitive carrying on and emphasizing the possessive idea contained in u(mete/rwn, cp. ad N. 46 ta\ sfe/ter' au)tw=n.
