a)pe/xesqe tw=n a)llotri/wn ktl: cp. Cic. de Offic. iii. 5 ceterum qui sibi licere uult aliena occupare, idem ius uidetur aliis concedere in sua.
ma=llon h)/: we should say ‘but rather’.

ou)de/teron ga\r . . . tou\s poiou=ntas, ‘for neither does giving nor receiving always mean the same thing, but, whenever either takes
place at the right moment and in accordance with virtue, it benefits the giver or the recipient.’

Obey me willingly; for those who are useful to me also benefit themselves. Imagine that I am always present in spirit, if not in person; this will act as a check upon you. Conceal nothing; secrecy implies guilt and only brings anxiety. Perform your civic duties openly, and no one can slander you. Test your actions by considering whether you would wish me to know of them. Denounce any wicked designs against me; otherwise you will be sharing in the guilt of my enemies. Consider that those who are innocent are fortunate, not those whose wrong doings escape detection.
mhde\ pro\s e(/n: a more emphatic form of pro\s mhde/n, as often.
mhd' e)me\ lh/sein: see note on E. 42 mh/te lanqa/nein.
w(=n . . . w(=n . . . w(=n: in each case for e)kei/nwn a(/, by relatival attraction.

peri\ ta\ kekrumme/na tw=n pragma/twn a)nagkai=on pollou\s fo/bous gi/gnesqai: the idea of conscience, which was not realized by the Greeks, is more fully developed in the later Latin writers; it is perhaps best stated by Seneca (Ep. xliii) Quid prodest recondere se et oculos hominum auresque uitare? Bona scientia turbam aduocat, mala etiam in solitudine anxia atque sollicita est. Si honesta sunt quae facis, omnes sciant; si turpia, quid refert neminem scire, cum tu scias?
texnikw=s: here in a bad sense; see note on E. 73.
a(plw=s: see note on ad N. 46.

 ponhrou\s o)/ntas, ‘harbouring evil designs against my rule’; probably a purposely vague expression.
e)cele/gxete: e)le/gxein, ‘to prove,’ e)cele/gxein, ‘to prove in the wrong’, ‘expose’.

tou\s sugkru/ptontas, ‘those who assist in the concealment.’ su/n in composition has two forces, both of which can be illustrated from the uses of sugkru/ptein, either (1) with the idea of co-operation as here and in Archid. 102 ai( me\n ga\r eu)tuxi/ai . . . ta\s kaki/as sugkru/ptousin, or (2) intensifying, cp. Trap. 18 sugkru/yai th\n sumfora/n, ‘completely hide.’
toi=s a(marta/nousin: dative after th=s au)th=s.

Do not establish political clubs without my sanction. My friendship is surest and safest. Preserve the existing order of things; political changes often affect the individual adversely. The mildness or severity of a ruler depends on the conduct of his subjects. My safety means your security. Abide by my commands, and seek to be conspicuous only in the splendour of your public services.

e(tairei/as mh\ poiei=sqe: the word e(tairei=ai originally meant ‘brotherhoods’ or ‘clubs’, the purpose of which was probably usually social, though they were sometimes religious in character. Such ‘clubs’ soon lost their original character and became political; though before the Persian wars, if we are to believe Isocrates (ta\s e(tairei/as sunh=gon ou)x u(pe\r tw=n i)di/a| sumfero/ntwn a)ll' e)pi\ th=| tou= plh/qous w)felei/a|, Paneg. 79), their object was a patriotic one. During the Peloponnesian War the term comes to be applied to the followers of great statesmen such as Cimon and Pericles. But they were increasingly employed for unconstitutional purpose; the best example of this is perhaps the use made of them by Alcibiades in 412 B.C. The e(tairei=ai became a constant source of danger in Greek political life at Athens, and Isocrates is no doubt giving voice to his own feelings when he puts these words into the mouth of Nicocles.
suno/dous, ‘gatherings’ of a more general kind than the organized e(tairei=ai.

e)n tai=s a)/llais politei/ais: Isocrates is perhaps thinking of the use made by Lysander of the e(tairei=ai in the Greek cities of Asia Minor, where he either used existing political organizations or founded others to assist the introduction of Spartan rule.
pleonektou=sin: used absolutely ‘are advantageous’; see note on E. 11.
e)n oi(=s: for the relative introducing a consecutive sentence see note on E. 35 ou)dei/s e)stin ou(/tw r(a/|qumos o(/stis.
kata/stasin: see note on § 26.
a)nasta/tous: see note on § 23.
h)\ kata/: Latin quam pro, cp. E. 21 h)\ kat' a)/nqrwpon.
mh\ ma=llon . . . h)/, ‘not so much . . . as.’
u(mete/ran au)tw=n: see note on § 49.
to\n au)to\n tro/pon kai\ ta\ peri\ u(ma=s e(/cei, ‘your fortunes will be of the same kind.’ peri\ u(ma=s, hiatus, as often after peri/.

tai=s u(pe\r th=s po/lews leitourgi/ais, ‘services towards the state.’ The kings of Salamis had apparently copied the Athenians in imposing ‘public services’ on the wealtheir citizens. At Athens the leitourgi/ai were, in time of peace (a) xorhgi/a, the expense of producing a play; (b) e(sti/asis, the provision of a feast for fellowtribesmen; (c) gumnasiarxi/a, the expense of a gymnasium; in war (a) trihrarxi/a, the equipment of a trireme; (b) ei)sfora/, the special war-tax.

Educate the younger generation by example as well as by precept. Teach them to be loyal subjects, for good subjects made good rulers. Remember that the best thing that you can bequeath to your children is my good will. Those who prove themselves untrustworthy are miserable; they live in fear, for they can rely on no one's help.
tou\s u(mete/rous au)tw=n: for the genitive see note on § 49.
e)qi/zet' au)tou\s . . . diatri/bein: cp. ad N. 29 e)/qize sauto\n xai/rein.
kalw=s a)/rxesqai, ‘to be good subjects.’ For the sentiment cp. Cic. de Leg. iii. 2 qui modeste paret, uidetur qui aliquando imperet dignus esse.
kinduneu/sousi peri\ tw=n u(parxo/ntwn: lit. ‘they will run risks concerning the things which belong to them already’, so ‘they will be in danger of losing what they already possess’.
me/giston . . . katalei/pein, ‘consider that you will be leaving them great and righteous wealth, if you can bequeath them our good will.’
to\n e)pi/loipon xro/non: see note on E. 27 to\n a)/llon xro/non.

Envy not the rich but the righteous. Virtue is superior to vice not only in reputation but in real worth. Do not be jealous of those whom I favour, but emulate their deeds. Be loyal not merely in word but in deed. Do not do to others what you would not wish to suffer yourself. Do not practice what you yourself condemn. Let my word be law to you. In short, behave towards me as you would have your inferiors behave towards you.
yuxh=s: see note on E. 23.
to\ d' o)/noma dusxere/steron e)/xein, ‘and that it is only its name which is uglier.’
duna/meis, ‘qualities’; see note § 9.
toi=s proe/xousin, ‘those who hold the first place’; proe/xein is here used absolutely.
tugxa/nhte tw=n au)tw=n, ‘may meet with the same treatment’; i.e. win my affection and honour at my hands.
h)\ e)n: Isocrates allows a hiatus after h)/, cp. Helen. 8 where the MSS. read h)\ o( and similarly h)\ e)xqro/s, de bigis 42.

peri\ w(=n a)\n e)n toi=s lo/gois kathgorh=te: the usual construction after kathgorei=n is the acc. of the thing and the genitive of the person, but the gen. of the person (here omitted) and peri/ with the genitive of the thing is also found. For the sentiment cp. Diog. Laert. i. 36 *qalh=s e)rwthqei\s pw=s a)\n a)/rista kai\ dikaio/tata biw/saimen, e)a/n, e)/fh, a(\ toi=s a)/llois e)pitimw=men, au)toi\ mh\ drw=men.

toiau=ta prosdoka=te pra/cein ktl, ‘expect your fortune to be such as are your thoughts about us.’ pra/ssein often means ‘to fare’ (eu)= pra/ssein, ‘to fare well’; cp. the colloquial English ‘to do well’); toiau=ta is here used adverbially with it.
toi=s ma/lista poiou=sin u(mw=n a(gw\ bou/lomai, ‘those of you who best carry out my wishes.’ u(mw=n is partitive genitive.

kefa/laion tw=n ei)rhme/nwn, ‘to sum up what I have said’; cp. Dem. de Cor. 213 to\ d' ou)=n kefa/laion: h)ci/oun ktl. For the omission of e)sti/ cp. E. 8 shmei=on de\ me/giston and similar phrases quoted in note.
oi(/ous . . . gi/gnesqai: for the sentiment cp. Seneca, Ep. xlvii sic cum inferiore uiuas quemadmodum tecum superiorem uelles uiuere.

I need not dwell on the happiness and prosperity which will accrue from your loyal obedience. They would be worth a great sacrifice; which, however, is unnecessary. You need only act faithfully and justly.
h)\n . . . ta\ par' u(mw=n u(phreth=tai: for h)\n u(mei=s u(phreth=te, translate ‘if your support is given me’.
oi(=o/n per: sc. parei=xon.
to\n u(me/teron au)tw=n: see note on § 49.
e)pidedwko/ta: see note on E. 7 e)pido/seis. The perfect participle here expresses immediate result.
mhde\n e)llei/pein: lit. ‘to fail in nothing’, so ‘to leave nothing undone’ (F.). For e)llei/pein see note on ad N. 33.
ou(stinasou=n: strictly speaking this is a case of attraction for oi(tinesou=n ei)si, since o(stisou=n, ‘whoever,’ introduces an indefinite relative clause; cp. the use of the Latin quicumque.
mhde\n talaipwrhqei=sin, ‘without any painful effort.’
